HEADLINE: The Best Film With the Smallest Release

BYLINE: By NATHAN LEE

 BODY:
WHEN historians of the future look back on the current movie scene, they will note the presence of giants among us, and marvel that they passed by so little noticed. On the film festival circuit and in the pages of serious film magazines, the names are already legend, but in what remains of the art-house culture in America, their reputations are barely a whisper. Wong Kar-wai, Jia Zhangke, Hou Hsiao-hsien, Tsai Ming-liang: the great foreign filmmakers of our time sound more foreign than ever.
 If we have learned, at least, the first name in this pantheon -- no one who has seen ''In the Mood for Love'' could ever forget the man behind such voluptuous romanticism -- we're still fumbling with Jia Zhangke, whose piercing vision of young Chinese negotiating cultural shift on the mainland (''Platform,'' ''Unknown Pleasures'') humbles the Sundance solipsism of our home-grown independents. There is a good reason an ardent coterie speaks of Hou Hsiao-hsien as passionately as they might of Hitchcock: ''Flowers of Shanghai,'' his dreamlike evocation of a 19th-century brothel, is an obsessive masterpiece to rank with ''Vertigo.'' And there's an even better reason this remains a minority view: Mr. Hou has seen exactly one of his films properly distributed in the United States. 
 Tsai Ming-liang, whose latest film opens Friday, has fared slightly better. About a year after its highly acclaimed local premiere at the New York Film Festival, ''Goodbye, Dragon Inn'' is finally getting a commercial run, at the Cinema Village. Almost all of Mr. Tsai's features have received limited theatrical runs, and the adventurous distributor Wellspring keeps them available on DVD. 
 Will ''Goodbye, Dragon Inn,'' arguably the greatest film ever made about moviegoing, finally imprint those four syllables in the minds of moviegoers? It's certainly not his most accessible picture. Like the methodical ''Platform'' and the hermetic ''Flowers of Shanghai,'' this subtle work makes unusual demands on the viewer.
 Clocking in at just over 80 minutes, the modestly scaled ''Goodbye, Dragon Inn'' doesn't sound like much of a challenge to audiences. Set almost entirely inside a decrepit Taipei movie house during its final show (a screening of the classic swordplay flick ''Dragon Inn''), the film is steeped in pleasant melancholia and wistful cinephilia. But with no more than a sprinkling of dialogue, the slimmest of plots and scarcely a camera movement in sight, it prizes quiet over clamor, stillness over spectacle and reflection over stimulation.
 Yet, for all of the demands of its style, it is immediately recognizable as a variation on a familiar genre, the study in ''urban alienation.'' What slowly becomes apparent is that ''Goodbye, Dragon Inn'' is many other things as well: a poem of erotic triangulation, a deadpan comedy paced like peeling wallpaper, a subtle Buddhist ghost story. The cumulative effect is far from alienating; Mr. Tsai's sixth feature is as gentle and generous as movies come -- once you've learned to speak its language.
 The first step toward fluency is to adjust your sense of rhythm and tone: ''Goodbye, Dragon Inn'' brings to perfection one of the most exacting visual styles in contemporary movies -- it's minimalism to the max. Mr. Tsai arranges his material into meticulous horizontal compositions (not unlike certain late Jasper Johns paintings), then contemplates them over several minutes from a medium-to-far distance. His first four films, at least, are full of movement, but the glacial elegance of his pans and tracking shots gives an overall impression of stasis.
 Once you've become accustomed to Mr. Tsai's voice, it might help to look into his previous usage: complete in itself, ''Goodbye, Dragon Inn'' nevertheless gains significant resonance through familiarity with the faces, themes and ideas of the Tsai oeuvre. ''Rebels of a Neon God,'' ''Vive l'Amour,'' ''The River,'' ''The Hole,'' ''What Time Is It There?'' and ''Goodbye, Dragon Inn'' constitute a beguiling achievement -- a suite of tragicomedies about metropolitan life from the mind of a scrupulous gay minimalist with Buddhist tendencies and an obsessive fixation on the metaphorical possibilities of water. Taken together, they create an irreducibly strange yet coherent universe.
 At the center of this universe rests the actor Lee Kang-sheng. Usually playing the reticent, beleaguered Hsiao Kang, he serves as a surrogate for the director, an object of contemplation and something of a pinup (Mr. Lee in tighty whities is one of Mr. Tsai's most dependable motifs). Hsiao Kang has been compared to that better-known directorial surrogate, Antoine Doinel in the semiautobiographical films of Francois Truffaut. But this listless, impassive hero deadpans his way through these pictures more like a busted Buster Keaton.
 In ''Rebels of the Neon God,'' he is a troubled dropout acting under the influence of his simmering sexual identity; among other things, Mr. Tsai's debut film is a not-quite-coming-out story. In ''Vive l'Amour'' Hsiao Kang is a salesman of crematorium urns who finds himself caught up in a kind of low-rent slow-motion sex farce; among other things, Mr. Tsai's second film is an oblique study of the marginally employed.
 Hsiao Kang goes from anxious to agonized in the third film, Mr. Tsai's bold masterwork ''The River.'' Hsiao Kang, now unemployed (or so it seems: the films are structured around absences and ambiguities), becomes afflicted with an excruciating neck condition. Various cures prove ineffective until he seeks alleviation in the dark, steam-filled chambers of a gay bathhouse, where, in a nightmare tableau, he grapples with his own father.
 True relief finally (almost?) arrives with the song and dance numbers of ''The Hole,'' an apocalyptic musical -- you heard right -- about two lonely neighbors joined in unexpected intimacy by a plumber's goof.
 And the fifth film, ''What Time Is It There?,'' finds Hsiao Kang dividing his time between vending cheap watches on a pedestrian skywalk and obsessively setting every clock in Taipei to Paris time in a kind of abstract solidarity with one of his vacationing customers. 
 Mr. Lee is only the most persistent figure in Mr. Tsai's stock company. The squinty actor Miao Tien has three times played Hsaio Kang's implacable father. Together with Lu Yi-ching as his superstitious mother, an enormous tropical fish named Fatty and a couple of cockroaches, they form an entropic nuclear family that Mr. Tsai returns to again and again.
 Although the father character dies in the first scene of ''What Time Is It There?,'' there's every reason to suspect he'll be back, in one form or another, in Mr. Tsai's next feature, ''A Cloud at the Edge of the Sky.'' After all, in the final image of ''Time,'' he has rematerialized poolside in a Paris park, with a mischievous glint in his eye.
 Mr. Tsai's characters are never far from water. It pours down from clouds, gurgles up from drains, nourishes potted plants, oozes rot into shabby sheetrock walls. People drink it, bathe in it, monitor its evaporation rate (to check for the presence of thirsty ghosts) and urinate it with memorable on-screen frequency. Mr. Tsai never lets us forget that we're largely made up of the stuff: Simply put, his movies are about thirsty people trying to stay dry, and that's about as sly a way of expressing the human condition as a filmmaker has come up with. 
 In ''Goodbye, Dragon Inn,'' the movie theater provides shelter from the storm outside -- an indication that Mr. Tsai is addressing his audience with newfound directness. His characters are often encountered in movie theaters, as well as public restrooms, elevators, cheap hotels, hallways and other anonymous zones in the urban landscape. As Kent Jones notes in his perceptive essay ''Here and There: The Films of Tsai Ming-liang,'' the director's observation of city life is focused on places where the public and private commingle and the psycho social energies that course through them. ''Goodbye, Dragon Inn'' adjusts this attention to a laser point, stepping outdoors only once, in the final image.
 As the film begins, a silent cashier (Chen Shiang-chyi) sits sequestered in her box office plucking morsels off a pink pork bun. After carefully wrapping the unfinished half, she tramps through the damp corridors of the theater, her clubfoot sounding a rueful click-clomp against the muffled soundtrack of the movie playing on the screen. Ascending to the projection booth, she finds it empty and leaves the gift behind. This takes the better part of 10 minutes and constitutes one of the film's major plot developments: ''Goodbye, Dragon Inn'' attenuates narrative incident until it nearly evaporates off the screen. Mr. Tsai's famously long takes now stretch a tentative hand toward eternity -- all of which is appropriate for a ghost story set in a movie theater. 
 As the cashier completes her miniature odyssey, a young Japanese man (Kiyonobu Mitamura) squirms in his seat, not watching ''Dragon Inn.'' He's distracted by two lipsmacking patrons on his left, a pair of bare feet dangling over the seat to his right and the various gay men cruising the room. The art of cruising -- a silent seduction of the glance, fraught with anxiety, sent out to clarify identity -- is another of Mr. Tsai's original themes. The extraordinary insight of ''Goodbye, Dragon Inn'' is to conflate this erotic mode with the tender supplication of moviegoing itself.
 Careful eyes will note that the film begins with a shot of a capacity audience that has mysteriously vanished when we next peek inside. This is a room full of ghosts. Present in the audience are several of the actors who are on screen in ''Dragon Inn,'' including, of all people, Hsiao Kang's father, Miao Tien. There is also a woman who appears to have been eating sunflower seeds forever, to judge by the evidence scattered on the floor. And Hsiao Kang? It wouldn't do to spoil one of the most delightful ideas in all of Tsai. Suffice it to say, he ends up the ''hero'' once again. 
 Is it all so difficult? No one goes into an exhibit of abstract art grousing about the lack of subject: you won't get much from this delicate movie if you wonder why nothing's happening. Relax your expectations of how fast a plot should move -- or, really, whether there must be a plot at all -- and you may feel your imagination reaching deep into the quiet, open spaces of ''Goodbye, Dragon Inn.'' And what you find there is your self, in the act of watching a movie -- and maybe the cute person checking you out across the aisle.

HEADLINE: Memories in High Relief

BYLINE: By JAMES E. YOUNG. 
James E. Young, chairman of the department of Judaic and Near Eastern studies at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst, is the author, most recently, of ''At Memory's Edge.'' He served on the World Trade Center Memorial design jury.

 BODY:
While a lot of attention has been paid to the 9/11 memorial in Lower Manhattan, not enough has been focused on the memorials that are springing up throughout Long Island, Westchester and New Jersey. That's a shame, because each has a special importance. And with each new design or proposal, more questions arise: When are there enough memorials? Does every town have to have its own? 
 In the face of difficult, even combative discussions about the design and location of memorials, some even voice the fear that the very memorials they hope will unite a community around its grief have actually become divisive and alienating, an unseemly airing of local political laundry. 
 Take Chappaqua, N.Y.. While the town has now decided to build a memorial to the three residents who were killed on Sept. 11, 2001, it took a year, a lawsuit (which was eventually thrown out) and much discussion for the townspeople to come to that decision. Naturally, no one wanted to be seen as against a memorial, but many had legitimate concerns about the proposed location and the traffic it might bring. Others argued that the proposed design, which included steel beams from the World Trade Center, was too graphic and offensive. 
 It might be helpful for those feeling bruised by the Chappaqua debate to remember that memorialization is a long and sometimes agonizing process, one that began immediately after the towers fell in September 2001. The first memorials to the 9/11 attacks and their victims came in the posted fliers of the missing, the candles and vigils at Union Square, on the Esplanade in Brooklyn Heights, and elsewhere around the city.
 These photos and descriptions of loved ones were the first spontaneous commemorations of loss and grief. With their pictures and descriptions of loving fathers, mothers, sons and daughters, these fliers read almost as epitaphs on paper instead of stone, as perishable and transitory as the hope that inspired them. These families' missing loved ones were, in turn, remembered and mourned by all who came across these ''found memorials.'' 
 Further stages of memorialization included the ever-changing landscape of destruction at ground zero. Where the seven-story mountain of tangled and jutting ruins stood literally as a remnant of the ferocity of the attack and mass death, the gigantic hole in the ground now stands literally for the immeasurable void left in our lives and hearts, an open wound in the cityscape.
 The feverish pace of attempted rescue and clean-up leading to the brink of rebuilding downtown bespeaks the need of all to remember this terrible breach by repairing it. Indeed, many still feel that the best memorial to those who died on Sept. 11 is the rebuilding of the site itself, a place where lives lost would be commemorated by new buildings and new lives lived. 
 From the outset, however, the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation has wisely taken a long and capacious view of its mission, which might be summarized in its motto, ''Remember, Rebuild, Renew.'' What has also become clear in all of these memorials -- from Michael Arad and Peter Walker's winning design for ground zero to Frederic Schwartz's sublime sculptural assembly of ascending steel rods in Valhalla, N.Y., to the commemorative scattering of petals in the surf at Point Lookout Park on Long Island's South Shore -- is that the memorialization of the 9/11 attacks and their victims must be seen as a process, a process that is in many ways the life-blood of memory itself. 
 For as a process, every memorial demands its own space and time, its own competition, its own debate and negotiated result. As a process, the memorial is animated and sustained by the public give and take, the debates, the constant working through. 
 In this view, the welcome advent of memorials to the victims of the 9/11 attacks in every borough of the city, as well as in nearly every neighboring suburb, is perfectly understandable. From New York City to Westchester to Long Island and New Jersey, every community deserves its own memorial, one that reflects its particular losses, ways of mourning and understanding of these terrible events. 
 Memory is necessarily repetitive, but these memorials are anything but redundant. Each should have its own process, one that is as messy and noisy as the next. Despite the well-intentioned offers to unify the necessarily disparate memories of different regions with 9/11 icons (like the twin beams or steel fragments of the towers), every community must take the time to find its own expression, on its own terms. 
 Some will conduct full-scale competitions, and others will invite native artists to help them articulate their grief. But if all see their memorials as processes, each a part of an over-arching process larger than themselves, all will give themselves room to remember as they see fit. 
 After all, these 9/11 memorials are both personal and public, individual and communal. In the spaces of these memorials, mourners come to remember the victims of 9/11 together -- and separately. There will always be room in these memorials for both kinds of memory.

HEADLINE: Downside As Deficit Deepens

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
A GOVERNMENT report on Tuesday about the current account deficit for the second quarter is likely to prompt new concerns about the value of the dollar. 
 The current account measures the country's balance of trade in goods and services with the rest of the world. It is expected to be a deficit of $158 billion for the second quarter, raising the total for the first six months of the year to about $303 billion, more than 11 percent higher than the deficit for the first six months of 2003. 
 At that rate, the deficit could top $600 billion for the year, swamping the record of $531 billion set last year.
 Currency strategists worry that the deficit must be covered by money from abroad, and that if this flow slows down, interest rates may go higher and the dollar lower.
 Despite the growth in the deficit, the dollar has been relatively stable for the last several months; it is actually up for the year against both the euro and the Japanese yen -- maybe because the foreign funds flow into the United States has been speeding up, not slowing down. 
 In the first six months of the year, foreigners bought a net $440.5 billion of American stocks and bonds, up from $326.3 billion in the first six months of 2003, according to Treasury Department figures adjusted to fully reflect the net inflow of foreign money.
 That flow is well ahead of the size of the current account deficit. But one major concern is that a large part of this money is coming from foreign central banks, especially those in China and Japan.
 So far this year, official foreign institutions, which include central banks, have bought 30 percent, or $150.6 billion, of the $504.3 billion that foreigners spent on United States Treasury, agency and corporate bonds, before special adjustments. That is up from $56.1 billion, or 15.6 percent, in the first six months of 2003.
 Just going back to the 2003 pace would lower the adjusted inflow to about $370 billion, so a change in the appetite of other foreign investors could quickly make the current account deficit very troubling.

DATA RUSH -- This week's data will provide a broad measure of the economy's well-being. A report on Tuesday on August retail sales is expected to show a decline of 0.1 percent, according to Bloomberg News, but that is mostly because of a slowdown in auto sales. Retail sales, excluding autos, are expected to rise 0.2 percent, matching the July gain.
 Industrial production for August, to be reported Wednesday, is expected to show a jump of 0.5 percent, after a 0.4 percent climb in July. The Consumer Price Index for August, due on Thursday, is predicted to rise 0.2 percent, after a 0.1 percent decline in July.

SECTION: Section 7; Column 1; Book Review Desk; New & Noteworthy Paperbacks; Pg. 28

LENGTH: 731 words

BYLINE: By Ihsan Taylor

 BODY:

LOOT: And Other Stories, by Nadine Gordimer. (Penguin, $14.) This structurally diverse collection, Gordimer's first since 1991, the year she won the Nobel Prize, offers portraits of characters bowed by the complicated burden of loss. In the title story, set in the aftermath of a devastating earthquake, tragedy and opportunity present themselves in equal measure. ''At times ironic, at others enraged, defiant or rueful, the work gathered here reflects the unflinching ferocity of its author's imagination,'' Claire Messud said in the Book Review last year.

WHERE I WAS FROM, by Joan Didion. (Vintage International, $13.95.) In a radically revisionary book, Didion combines history and reportage, memoir and literary criticism, to reassess her home state, California. She now sees the state's past, which she once mythologized, as a saga of ruthless self-sufficiency. Thomas Mallon, writing in the Book Review in 2003, called it ''a fascinating gloss'' on Didion's earlier writings, ''something that will be appreciated especially by longtime admirers.''

ON THE NATURE OF HUMAN ROMANTIC INTERACTION, by Karl Iagnemma. (Delta, $13.) Art imitates oddly specific lives in this debut collection of short stories. Iagnemma, a recipient of a Pushcart Prize, is also a robotics researcher at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology; his characters, all scientists, wrestle with love and life outside academia (one tries unsuccessfully to diagram his relationship with his girlfriend). Last year our reviewer, Jim Holt, found these stories ''richly imagined and laced with delicate ironies.''

CITY OF GLASS, by Paul Auster. Adaptation by Paul Karasik and David Mazzucchelli. (Picador, $14.) Ten years ago Karasik and Mazzucchelli reinvented Auster's 1985 existentialist mystery as a graphic novel, which deepened its noir-inflected darkness. In a 1998 essay in the Book Review, Tom De Haven called Mazzucchelli's blunt, bold lines ''formally brilliant.'' This edition includes a new introduction by Art Spiegelman.

JUST WAR AGAINST TERROR: The Burden of American Power in a Violent World, by Jean Bethke Elshtain. (Basic Books, $14.) Elshtain, a professor of ethics at the University of Chicago, advocates an ethic of responsibility in pursuing a ''just war'' on terrorism. Her treatise leaves behind ''a well-trimmed swath of intellectual clarity,'' Paul Berman wrote in these pages last year.

IN AN UNCERTAIN WORLD: Tough Choices From Wall Street to Washington, by Robert E. Rubin and Jacob Weisberg. (Random House, $16.95.) As a steward of the long economic expansion of the 1990's, Rubin may be the best-known Treasury secretary since Andrew W. Mellon. This memoir recounts his early days on Wall Street before turning to the economic crises during the Clinton administration's second term. In 2003 our reviewer, David Warsh, called this ''a gem of a book.'' Rubin's isn't the only commentary on President Clinton's tumultuous second term. In THE CLINTON WARS (Plume, $18), Sidney Blumenthal, a presidential adviser from 1997 to 2001, staunchly defends the former president and first lady against the ''vast right-wing conspiracy'' that, the author argues, was all too real. Blumenthal ''brings a reporter's keen eye for telling detail and a columnist's talent for considered analysis and unmistakable opinion,'' Robert Dallek said here last year.

EMPIRE: The Rise and Demise of the British World Order and the Lessons for Global Power, by Niall Ferguson. (Basic Books, $17.95.) The author, an eminent British historian, sees America as both the offspring of and heir to Britain's global domination and traces key features of the modern world -- capitalism, education, parliamentary democracy -- to four centuries of British expansion. ''Ferguson writes with his usual verve,'' Margaret MacMillan wrote in the Book Review last year, ''and takes a few swipes at sacred cows along the way.''

MASTER OF DREAMS: A Memoir of Isaac Bashevis Singer, by Dvorah Telushkin. (Perennial/HarperCollins, $13.95.) Telushkin captures the evolution of her 12-year apprenticeship to Singer -- from secretary to editor and translator -- in this series of poetic vignettes. The author, a storyteller by profession, shares the great moments in Singer's public life (as well as his private torments). Her ''lovely prose evokes the atmosphere of a vanishing way of life,'' Andrea Cooper wrote here in 1997. Ihsan Taylor

LENGTH: 1077 words

HEADLINE: In California, Students Find Housing Lucrative

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS GRUDIN

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES 

 BODY:
FOR about a year or so, Efren Ramirez, 20, a pre-med student at Santa Monica College, had been paying $900 a month for a small studio apartment and shared bathroom. Knowing that he had many years of school ahead, Mr. Ramirez decided that spending money on rent didn't make sense, and he started looking for an alternative. 
 Last summer, with financial assistance from his parents and his fiancee at the time, Mr. Ramirez bought a condo a mile from the U.C.L.A. campus, where he will enroll this winter. Today, because of the hot Southern California market, his modest one-bedroom unit, for which he paid $240,000, already has appreciated $110,000, and when he finds a roommate, his $1,700 mortgage payments will be halved. 
 ''A couple of years from now when I have to afford medical school, this will make it a lot easier,'' Mr. Ramirez said, strolling across the parquet flooring he recently installed in his living room. 
 Real estate agents say that parent-student buyers make up a notable contingent of the area's business. ''I get them all the time; smart people do that,'' said Coco Clayman-Cook, the assistant manager at Prudential California Realty's Beverly Hills office, who found Mr. Ramirez his condo.
 Here, and in other cities throughout the country where real estate has been a good investment, the practice seems to be growing more popular as more people decide that its economics are compelling. 
 In Westwood, the U.C.L.A. college town not far from Bel Air, Brentwood and Beverly Hills, rents for one-bedroom apartments are now about $1,500 a month. And while university administrators hope to guarantee campus housing for all undergraduates who want it, a plan to add thousands of rooms by the end of the decade could still leave about 23,000 students, graduate and undergraduate, looking for housing in Westwood and its pricey surroundings, according to Michael Foraker, director of housing at U.C.L.A. These factors, combined with California's rapidly appreciating housing market, have led real estate-savvy students and their parents to change their perspective on student housing. Instead of viewing it as a draining but necessary expense, they consider it a lucrative investment opportunity.
 ''It makes so much sense; you don't pay any rent and you make money on your investment -- you might be able to pay to put your kids through school,'' said Jack Kyser, chief economist for the Los Angeles County Economic Development Corporation, who has witnessed the same phenomenon in downtown Los Angeles near the University of Southern California.
 Likewise, a few hundred miles north, around the University of California at Berkeley, where housing prices have also skyrocketed, many students are now living in what are essentially investment properties, according to William Ktsanes, director of research and analysis for RealFacts, an apartment market research firm. ''Families looking at paying $1,500 a month for their child's apartment start considering buying a home and feel like it's a secure investment partially because it is in a college town and there will always be students that need housing there,'' he said.
 With today's low interest rates, the math works out well, provided that parents can afford the down payment on a condo, which for a one- or two-bedroom unit around U.C.L.A. would cost $350,000 to $500,000. Other considerations include homeowner's dues, property taxes and maintenance, but those expenses can be offset if the student is willing to live with a roommate or two. 
 Although Westwood real estate's recent appreciation of about 15 percent a year makes the decision to buy look particularly easy in retrospect, the market needs only moderate growth for the investment to pay off, according to Suzanne Frank, owner of Abbot Kinney Real Estate in Venice.
 Parents ''can go get a place and put in a down payment and put a few other kids in there and the other students' parents are paying their mortgage,'' said Ms. Frank, who has sold real estate on the west side of Los Angeles for 20 years. ''Not only are they going to get tax benefits, but they get the benefit of having their child living in a nice place -- their own home with their own kitchen -- and they're making money.'' 
 Emi Yoshida, 22, who graduated from U.C.L.A. in June with a double major in business economics and sociology, spent her junior and senior years living with three friends in a two-bedroom condo that her father, Michael Yoshida, bought in 2002. All of her roommates paid below-market rent and lived two to a room, just as they would have in dorms, but in this case their rent offset Mr. Yoshida's monthly costs.
 ''I was clearly comparing the numbers between paying rent versus ownership, with the potential for a selling price that would make it a smart move at the end of a couple of years,'' said Mr. Yoshida, a San Francisco architect. ''I just went through the math on my own, and given the trend of how real estate is going down there, it made sense to do this.''
 For Ms. Yoshida, who is planning to move to New York City and seek work in public health, the arrangement was not only a good investment -- her condo has appreciated more than 30 percent since 2002 -- but also her first experience as a homeowner, acting as the de facto landlord, often dealing with renters who were people she knew. ''There's a business relationship that develops that's different from a friendship,'' she said. ''There were ups and downs to having it, but the good definitely outweighs the bad.''
 Naysayers are quick to point out that students like Ms. Yoshida are missing out on an important aspect of college -- campus life. But the young homeowners are gaining a different type of education, according to Richard Pon, 24, who is working toward a doctorate in electrical engineering at U.C.L.A. In May, Mr. Pon bought a condo eight miles away, in Culver City. His one-bedroom condo looks surprisingly similar to a dormitory room, complete with dead potted plants flanking a barbecue grill on his patio and a TV blocking the fireplace.
 Mr. Pon is already beginning to understand the responsibilities, and rewards, of owning a home.
 ''If something breaks, you can't just write a letter to the management,'' he said. ''When I clean something up, I'm cleaning it up for myself. It's like, would you wash a rental car?'' 
 So far, it seems worth it to him. ''It's a lot more work,'' he said, ''but there's a lot more personal value, too -- it's exciting.''


GRAPHIC: Photos: FANCY 'DORMS' -- Emi Yoshida, seated at right, and her roommate, Lani Nichols, relax in the condo that Ms. Yoshida's father purchased for her while she was attending U.C.L.A. Richard Pon, left, and Efren Ramirez, below, who are also students, have bought condos near the U.C.L.A. campus as well. (Photographs by Stephanie Diani for The New York Times) 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SECTION: Section 9; Column 1; Style Desk; A NIGHT OUT WITH -- Mia Maestro; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 658 words

HEADLINE: P.S.: They Left a Big Tip

BYLINE: By MARGY ROCHLIN

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES 

 BODY:
NO one could ever say that the Argentine actress Mia Maestro, who stars in the new movie ''Motorcycle Diaries,'' is not willing to try new things. Since she moved to Los Angeles five years ago from Buenos Aires, she has taken up boxing and barge fishing and has gone scuba diving with a school of 60 feeding sharks. 
 ''I get, like, obsessed,'' Ms. Maestro, 26, said, as she and her boyfriend, Ned Benson, 27, an actor and director, drove in their black S.U.V. from their West Hollywood apartment toward the quiet streets of downtown Los Angeles. ''When she falls in love with something new, it's incredible how much work she puts into mastering it,'' Mr. Benson said. 
 Fans of the spy series ''Alias,'' in which Ms. Maestro plays Jennifer Garner's long-lost half-sister, Nadia, already know she can sprint breathlessly and survive a mysterious green goo injection, but they might be less familiar with her cultural side. Ms. Maestro's singing became the subject of debate a half-hour later as she and Mr. Benson sat in a nook at the Golden Gopher lounge having before-dinner drinks with their friends Sarah Watson, a director at the Gagosian Gallery in Beverly Hills, and her husband, Hardy Ophuls, a television producer.
 Mr. Benson suggested that Ms. Maestro's classically trained pealing-bell soprano -- featured in movies like ''Tango'' (she also dances) and ''Timecode'' -- defines karaoke buzz kill. Ms. Maestro took a brave stab at defending her amateur-hour credentials. ''The key is always wrong,'' she said. Mr. Benson groaned affectionately. ''At least you know what a key is,'' he said.
 Five minutes later, Ms. Maestro and her gang stood tentatively in the entryway of Kokekokko, a noisy Japanese restaurant in Little Tokyo, where she had a reservation. Ms. Maestro, twice one of Maxim magazine's 100 Sexiest Women, has often played pillow-lipped hot aristocrats, like the girlfriend of Che Guevara in ''The Motorcycle Diaries.'' But when the young maitre d' kept delaying her seating, she went straight into take-charge Nadia mode.
 Striding past packed wooden tables, she peeked into an empty rice-paper-walled room, then returned for some persistent finagling. The owner acquiesced, but only very reluctantly. Off came the shoes, and on came the charm. 
 ''I so desperately want them to like us,'' admitted Ms. Watson, who took pains to say, ''Thank you!'' each time a waitress entered the private room with trays of beer, hot sake, pickled radish and skewers of vegetables and poultry. Though Kokekokko's house specialty, chicken sashimi, might sound inedible to some people, Ms. Maestro has ''bring-it-on'' taste buds. ''I've eaten grasshopper tacos, ant eggs and maguey worms,'' she said cheerfully.
 She closed her brown eyes and heaved a blissful sigh. ''I've been dreaming of eating this,'' she said, biting into chicken liver (cooked, not raw) on a stick.
 Suddenly, a loud rap was heard on the door, and the maitre d' appeared. A few minutes of tense silence passed. Later, Ms. Watson said she thought he had come to throw everybody out.
 But no. Eyes fixed on Ms. Maestro, he confessed that he had given her table to a regular customer. Then his knees hit the tatami mat for a deep, apologetic bow.
 ''It's O.K.,'' Ms. Maestro said reassuringly as he stumbled out the door. Then the room exploded in relieved laughter.
 By 11, Ms. Maestro and Mr. Benson were speeding back to West Hollywood. Ms. Maestro had to be up early enough the next day to walk her dog, River, before reporting at 5 a.m. to the set of ''Alias,'' now taping its new season. Just blocks from home, talk turned to -- what else? -- parents. Ms. Maestro's mother is a former economist; her father is a businessman in Argentina.
 Do they like her movies?
 Mr. Benson laughed, a fond yet significant laugh.
 ''They're cinephiles,'' Ms. Maestro said, ''so they critique everything, scene by scene, what they like, what they don't. I actually try to forget what they tell me.''


GRAPHIC: Photo: SASHIMI-BOUND -- Mia Maestro and Ned Benson at Kokekokko. (Photo by Stephanie Diani for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk; CONSUMER AFFAIRS; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 1370 words

HEADLINE: Keeping Up With the Krogers

BYLINE: By TAMMY LA GORCE

 BODY:
TARUNI SETH, a mother of two who lives in Berkeley Heights may not know it, but she is a hot commodity in New Jersey grocers' circles. Her family's monthly grocery bill may seem insignificant in an industry that sells tens of millions of dollars in products statewide, but because she divides her time between Stop & Shop, Whole Foods and Kings, her shopping dollars are at play. 
 And in one of the country's most hotly contested markets, not being loyal to one store is akin to being an undecided voter during an election year. Only instead of two major parties, there are at least half-dozen stores trying to gain her good graces. And instead of stump speeches, there are limitless incentives.
 If Ms. Seth made it out to the Branchburg ShopRite, for example, she would find that children under 9 who spend time in the store-staffed playhouse can get manicures. Or if she were in the Tom's River area, she would be able to use her shopping dollars at Foodtown to earn enough points for a waffle maker or a pearl necklace. 
 A bit closer to home, the Raritan Stop & Shop offers convenience rather than freebies: drivers can maneuver their minivans past the store entrance and wait while groceries that were ordered online are loaded in the back.
 These stores are no exception. Grocery stores and supermarkets across the state are seeking to lure and retain customers with promotions that go well beyond listing markdowns on store circulars. Tidy aisles have sprouted a surplus of bells and whistles, seeking to establish themselves as suburban centers where everything from day care to banking to cooking lessons are available. 
 While regional grocery retailers in other states were swallowed in the late 90's by supermarket giants like Kroger, New Jersey's powerhouse grocers -- Kings, A.&P., Pathmark, ShopRite and Foodtown all are headquartered here -- were spared, clearing the way for a statewide, share-hungry battleground among the holdouts in a state that experts say has a particularly tight market. Larger chains with headquarters elsewhere have joined the fray as well in a bid to outdo their New Jersey-based competitors. The result: a dizzying flurry of supermarket enhancements that shows no sign of letting up. 
 While that may be something of a victory for the shoppers, it is a sign that the battle continues among a crowded field of grocery store and supermarket owners.
 ''It's become way more difficult,'' said Phil Scaduto, a vice president of marketing for Foodtown, a cooperative that has 52 outlets throughout the state. Mr. Scaduto's grandfather John Azzolina opened the first Foodtown market in Highlands in the 1920's. ''There are bigger players now, and the larger chains are moving in, so that a lot of groups like us have gone by the wayside.''
 Not only do the state's grocers face competition from supermarket giants such as Stop & Shop, a Quincy, Mass.,-based company whose 53 stores in New Jersey make up more than a seventh of its total, and from ACME, based in Malvern, Pa., which has 61 of its 138 stores in the state. Big box stores are also encroaching on the grocers' traditional turf. 
 ''We can't just myopically look at ShopRites, because we're also in competition with non-supermarkets,'' said Rich Savner, director of public affairs for Pathmark, based in Carteret. ''We have to consider the Walgreens, the Rite Aids, Costco, Sam's, Target and Wal-Mart and also the dollar stores that sell some of the same things we do.''
 Meredith Adler, senior equity analyst for Lehman Brothers, pointed out that such a highly splintered market is peculiar to the state. ''When you look at the market share data, it's very fragmented,'' she said. ''There are many players, and there's no big market shares.''
 But if there is any advantage to the regional chains' position, it is that they are in a part of the country where sprawling sites necessary to open stores like Wal-Mart are expensive, Ms. Adler added. Nationally, she said, the growth of nontraditional food sellers in New Jersey, ''is nothing compared to the rest of the country.'' 
 ''The economics make it hard for new players to come in, so there's a bias toward people who are already in the market,'' she said. 
 Regionals are trying hard to keep that bias tilted in their favor. Leading the pack, according to Mark Hamstra, retail and financial editor at industry trade magazine Supermarket News, is ShopRite. Wakefern, the co-op's supplier, which scans more than $7 billion in sales each year, ''is strong on its own -- historically on the cutting edge.'' '' 
 For ShopRite customers, that means a panoply of services few would associate with grocery stores. In addition to the Scrunchy's Playhouses, or in-store day care centers available at no cost to parents at a handful of stores, six New Jersey ShopRites have begun offering online ordering in the last year, with pick-up that does not require drivers to leave their vehicles. There are also self-checkout lanes, Dunkin' Donuts counters, T-Mobile cellphone dealers, North Fork Bank branches, dry cleaners, cigar shops, Chinese and pizza takeout counters, ''culinary workshops'' and loftlike seating areas for in-store dining. Foodtown, the smaller of the co-ops, lags by comparison. After an unsuccessful foray into self-checkouts in the early 90's, the company scotched the high-tech approach to drawing regulars. The focus is now on an incentive program that gives customers 10 points for every $100 spent; the points can be used toward food discounts or for products in a catalog that sells everything from bicycles to hairdryers.
 Cheryl Good, manager of community relations at Kings touted the chain's four cooking schools, in Bedminster, Hillsdale, Short Hills and Verona. The five-week intensive ''principles of cooking,'' which costs $150, mom-and-tot classes and demos by cookbook authors draw an affluent customer base, one attuned to ''the things that cost us a little bit more to operate, like higher standards for sanitation and quality.'' 
 Despite the emphasis on incentives and enhancements, where both co-operatives throw banana peels in the paths of their national competitors, said Ms. Adler of Lehman Brothers, is in their pricing. The regional stores can manage to keep their prices low. ''They can afford to do that because they have individual owners -- they're not trying to generate good profits every quarter,'' she said. ''They don't have any shareholders to please. Some of the owners are public, but they're very small.'' But the incentives may not pay off in the long run. Mr. Hamstra of Supermarket News noted: ''I don't have any data to show that any of these are working for the regionals. The thing is, they're competing with each other -- once one chain starts offering something they all feel they need to offer something. Nobody wants to let the other guy get a hand up.''
 It is unclear whether such promotions even figure in to shoppers' decisions. 
 Ms. Seth, the Berkeley Heights resident, favors Kings and Stop & Shop because ''they have special kids' carts the kids love.'' 
 But she responds to the old-fashioned way of netting customers. ''If they have a great sale at ShopRite or Pathmark, like a great deal on Coke, I'll end up going and buying 10 other things,'' she noted.
 Jill Johnson of South Orange, who regularly shops at ShopRite -- with occasional detours to Whole Foods -- seems to favor more high-tech incentives. ''I also do online ordering from the ShopRite in Clarke -- that's the closest one that has online ordering -- out of convenience. It's a lot easier to order food online and just go pick it up than to bring kids in the store,'' she noted.
 If Mr. Hamstra of Supermarket News's dire forecast for the regional grocers is true, shoppers should enjoy the scramble over their grocery dollars while they can. He suspects that modern-day New Jersey cart-pushers will wind up feeding at the same superstore trough as the rest of the country, and soon. 
 ''What's different about New Jersey that's not the case for most other states is that Wal-Mart Supercenters haven't opened here yet, and they're considered one of the main competitive threats to the industry.
 ''But eventually, it'll happen,'' he said. ''They'll come.''


GRAPHIC: Photos: The ShopRite in North Brunswick, left, provides day care. And at the Long Hill Plaza ShopRite, online orders are loaded into cars. (Photographs by Susan Stava for The New York Times)
