Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section 2; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk; THE NEW SEASON/CLASSICAL MUSIC; Pg. 74

LENGTH: 9197 words

HEADLINE: Bernstein And Bach, Zankel And Zippos

BYLINE: By JAMES R. OESTREICH; Compiled with the assistance of BEN SISARIO

 BODY:

Dates are subject to change.

September

LEONARD BERNSTEIN -- There are worse ways to open a season than with a wave of Bernsteiniana, new and old. While a new recording of Bernstein's ''Mass'' waits in the wings (Kent Nagano conducts the Deutsches Sinfonie-Orchester Berlin on Harmonia Mundi France, October), the Miller Theater at Columbia University opens its season with a Composer Portrait concert devoted to him. The violinist Jennifer Koh, the soprano Amy Burton and others join George Steel and the Gotham City Orchestra in works including the ''Serenade'' and excerpts from ''A Quiet Place'' and ''On the Town.'' Also this month -- lest in remembering Bernstein the composer we forget Bernstein the conductor and educator -- Kultur International Films is to release 25 of his celebrated Young People's Concerts with the New York Philharmonic on nine DVD's: a great boon at a time when music education is disappearing from schools. Next month Amadeus Press follows with a new printing of Bernstein's book ''The Joy of Music,'' accompanied by a DVD presenting two of his programs from the ''Omnibus'' TV series of the 1950's. Also next month, the WFMT Radio Network is to broadcast a new 11-part documentary series, ''Leonard Bernstein: An American Life,'' narrated by Susan Sarandon. That should all be as much talk and music as even the most avid Bernsteinian can ingest in a two-month period. But if anyone needs another fix long about, say, March, look for ''Candide'' at the New York City Opera. Composer Portrait, Saturday. Miller Theater.

SILK ROAD PROJECT -- Zankel Hall has proved mightily impressive since it opened a year ago, in both its acoustics and its amenities. Now, to open its second season, it begins to show how versatile it can be, going beyond the standard concert configuration, with the stage moved to the center and seats all around. But just as important as the hall's qualities is the direction its programming took in its first season, carrying its parent, Carnegie Hall, well beyond the standard repertory of Western classical music. So it is virtually tailor-made for the Silk Road Project, a venture Yo-Yo Ma set in motion several years ago to foster collaboration between Eastern and Western musicians. Here -- after a weeklong workshop on mentoring, creating and communicating at Tanglewood, in Lenox, Mass. -- the project offers a concentrated festival, with four evening concerts and various discussions. (Mr. Ma and the Silk Road Ensemble also perform in the Stern Auditorium at Carnegie on April 10.) Mr. Ma acknowledges no boundaries, and neither, it would seem, does his energy. Saturday-next Sunday. Zankel Hall and Weill Recital Hall.

'KOL NIDRE THROUGH THE AGES, AROUND THE WORLD' -- This event, under the artistic direction of the baritone Sanford Sylvan, is the flagship of both the 92nd Street Y's concert season and its season-long festival, ''Celebrate 350: Jewish Life in America, 1654-2004.'' Kol Nidre, a prayer central to the service for Yom Kippur, is performed in settings representing various traditions by cantors, a choir and instrumentalists. Next Sunday. 92nd Street Y.

'OTELLO' -- The Metropolitan Opera has restructured its season, with an earlier opening, a two-week break in January and a later close. The season begins in dead earnest here, as Ben Heppner sings the demanding title role of Verdi's opera for the first time at the Met. Barbara Frittoli sings Desdemona, Carlo Guelfi is Iago, and James Levine conducts. Opens Sept. 20. Metropolitan Opera House.

NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC -- The orchestra's season is mildly adventurous, but its opening night, typically, is not. Lorin Maazel conducts Beethoven's Violin Concerto, with Maxim Vengerov as soloist, and Dvorak's ''New World'' Symphony. The rest of the week (Sept. 22-24) ups the ante slightly. Mr. Vengerov switches to the Mendelssohn Concerto and Mr. Maazel to Beethoven's Seventh Symphony, but Mr. Maazel also adds Messiaen's ''Offrandes Oubliees.'' Opening night, Sept. 21. Avery Fisher Hall. www.nyphil.org

CHAMBER MUSIC SOCIETY OF LINCOLN CENTER -- The society begins a new season and a new era, with the pianist Wu Han and the cellist David Finckel taking over as music directors. Not that their arrival will affect this season's programming, which was pinned down long ago. The motley opening concert includes Stravinsky's ''Renard,'' a chamber version of Wagner's ''Siegfried Idyll'' and Berlioz's ''Nuits d'Ete'' and features a variety of performers. Sept. 22. Alice Tully Hall. www.chambermusicsociety.org. A related article is on Page 73.

'ELIJAH' -- Franz Welser-Most opens his third season as music director of the Cleveland Orchestra with a blockbuster, Mendelssohn's grand oratorio, with Thomas Quasthoff, a baritone of biblical authority, in the title role. Sept. 23, 25. Severance Hall, Cleveland, (216) 231-1111. www.clevelandorchestra.com

'DIE WALKURE' -- With Wagner's ''Ring'' cycle still resounding from the spring, the Met brings back the heart of its production, with a significant twist. Having taken over ''Parsifal'' last year, Valery Gergiev, the company's principal guest conductor, continues his incursion into repertory once the personal preserve of James Levine, as Mr. Levine turns some of his attention to the Boston Symphony. Olga Sergeeva makes her company debut as Brunnhilde, and Placido Domingo lends continuity as Siegmund. Opens Sept. 25. Metropolitan Opera House.

'NEW SOUNDS LIVE' -- John Schaefer of WNYC-FM is the host of a program of politically oriented music: Phil Kline's touching ''Zippo Songs,'' which take their texts from inscriptions by G.I.'s on their cigarette lighters in Vietnam; and excerpts from Scott Johnson's ''How It Happens,'' which applies sampling techniques to pronouncements of the journalist, political philosopher and provocateur I. F. Stone. Sept. 28. Merkin Concert Hall.

WALT DISNEY CONCERT HALL ORGAN -- A central feature of the Los Angeles Philharmonic's kicky new hall, designed by Frank Gehry, is a kicky new organ, with pipes that look like pick-up sticks. It is now evidently completely installed and ready to rumble. Frederick Swann gives the inaugural recital. Then the instrument is used in orchestral works that should tell just as much about its power and coloristic possibilities: Saint-Saens's ''Organ'' Symphony (Oct. 2-3) and Strauss's ''Also Sprach Zarathustra'' (Oct. 7, 9). Recital, Sept. 30. Walt Disney Concert Hall, Los Angeles, (323) 850-2000. www.laphil.org

October

NEW YORK EARLY MUSIC CELEBRATION -- Understandably weary of perennial laments from critics (including me) and others about the lackluster state of the early-music scene in New York, organizations and individuals in the area have decided to band together and show off their wares in some 60 events. Alas (here I go again), it's mostly small-bore stuff, and the festival has done little to get the word out to the public. Early Music New York, which spearheaded the effort, will perform at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola on Park Avenue on Oct. 2, presenting Handel's original festive orchestrations of the ''Royal Fireworks Music'' and the ''Water Music,'' with 58 players (12 of them oboists). (And what is it about early-musickers and puns? Whoever devised the title ''Lawes in Order'' should be roughed up by Detective Tutuola.) Oct. 1-10. Various locations. www.nyemc.org

BEAUX-ARTS TRIO -- Having celebrated his 80th birthday at the Met Museum last season with a variety of events, the revered pianist Menahem Pressler continues full steam ahead, leading his younger colleagues in a three-year survey of Beethoven trios and sonatas. Oct. 1, Dec. 10, April 1. Metropolitan Museum.

BRADLEY BROOKSHIRE -- For the last few years, this excellent harpsichordist has been experimenting with multimedia presentations of Bach's ''Art of Fugue,'' providing color-coded projections of the score, so listeners can follow the many bouncing balls. Presumably the operation is well oiled by now, with some of the early kinks worked out, and Mr. Brookshire presents it again on Oct. 20 at St. Bartholomew's Church on Park Avenue. In addition, he has recorded ''The Art of Fugue'' for release on an interactive CD-ROM with a crash course on the work. But first he expands on the experiment with a multimedia presentation of other keyboard fugues by Bach as part of the New York Early Music Celebration. Oct. 5. CUNY Graduate Center, 365 Fifth Avenue, at 34th Street. www.nyemc.org

PHILADELPHIA ORCHESTRA -- Hey, no pressure, folks, but remember, as you grapple with contract negotiations, you're supposed to open the Carnegie Hall season. Barring a strike, Christoph Eschenbach will conduct a program of Strauss, with Renee Fleming singing the ''Four Last Songs'' and Yo-Yo Ma playing ''Don Quixote.'' (At press time, in fact, with negotiations also looking dire at the Chicago Symphony, the Cleveland Orchestra and elsewhere, one is tempted to ask not whether there will be a strike this season, but how many there will be.) Oct. 6. Carnegie Hall.

'SUN RINGS' -- Taking his cue from sounds discovered in deep space, Terry Riley, a founding father of Minimalism, has conceived a multimedia meditation on the beauties of outer space and celestial harmonies. The Kronos Quartet is joined by the Dessoff Choirs, and Willie Williams supplies visual images. Oct. 6, 8, 9. Brooklyn Academy of Music.

'ROMEO AND JULIET' -- What Lorin Maazel does well he often does supremely well. For my money (and I've had to buy the thing several times when copies lent to grateful friends were never returned), his 1973 recording of Prokofiev's ''Romeo and Juliet'' with the Cleveland Orchestra is one of the great recordings ever made. Unfortunately, Mr. Maazel is doing only excerpts here with the New York Philharmonic (along with Prokofiev's Symphony No. 5 and Violin Concerto No. 1). He should perform the work complete again, and someone should record it. Oct. 7-9. Avery Fisher Hall.

'BACH IN CONTEXT' -- The pianist Christopher O'Riley joins the Academy of St. Martin in the Fields in ''Bach and the Classical Concerto,'' with works by C. P. E. Bach and Mozart, to open a six-concert series at the Miller Theater. The violinist Fabio Biondi and his ensemble Europa Galante follow with ''Bach and the Baroque Concerto.'' The Trigon String Trio then offers three concerts combining Bach with Purcell, Mozart and composers of the 20th century. And Alexandre Tharaud, a French pianist, makes his New York recital debut in a program of Bach, Couperin and Rameau. Oct. 7, 14, 29; March 18, 23; April 29. Miller Theater.

'DIE ZAUBERFLOTE' -- '' 'Magic Flute' Meets 'The Lion King' '' MusicalAmerica.com trumpeted in the headline to a review of Adrian Noble's production of the beloved Mozart opera at the Glyndebourne Festival last May. Perhaps, but here it does for sure. Julie Taymor, of ''Lion King'' fame, is both director and costume designer of a new production in her debut at the Met. James Levine conducts, and Matthias Goerne, who triumphed as Papageno five years ago in Achim Freyer's production at the Salzburg Festival, wearing balloonlike circus pants, repeats the role, wearing . . . well, who knows what? Opens Oct. 8. Metropolitan Opera House.

BEETHOVEN PIANO SONATAS -- Symphony Space has taken new directions in recent years, but it maintains a distinctive part of its franchise: marathon concerts. Here present and former students of the piano guru Leon Fleisher play all 32 of Beethoven's sonatas, from 11 a.m. to 11 p.m. Oct. 9. Symphony Space, Broadway at 95th Street, (212) 864-5400. www.symphonyspace.org

'MONTEVERDI EXTRAVAGANZA' -- As part of the New York Early Music Celebration, the vocal and instrumental ensemble Artek presents works by the Italian master, including ''Beatus Vir'' and duets and trios from the Seventh and Eighth Books of madrigals. There will also be a touch of dance (something Artek has done well before), set to Carlo Farina's ''Capriccio Stravagante.'' Oct. 9. Church of St. Francis of Assisi, 135 West 31st Street, (212) 967-9157. www.artekearlymusic.com.

ORCHESTRE SYMPHONIQUE DE MONTREAL -- You almost never hear Shostakovich's powerful cantata ''The Execution of Stepan Razin'' in concert. But Leon Botstein conducted it at the Bard Music Festival last month, and now James Conlon presents it again, along with another big choral work rare on the concert stage, Rachmaninoff's ''Bells.'' Oct. 10. Carnegie Hall.

'THE ROMANTIC GENERATION' -- If it's an illuminating combination of performance and intelligent discussion you're looking for, you won't do better than Charles Rosen, bringing his book of the same name to life. Today it's Chopin; later, Schumann, Mendelssohn and Brahms. Oct. 10, 24, Nov. 7. 92nd Street Y.

JOHN HARBISON-DAWN UPSHAW YOUNG ARTISTS CONCERT -- Here is an intriguing concept. In a workshop begun last May and to be completed Oct. 7 to 10, young singers and composers have been paired off to write and perform pieces for voice and chamber ensemble under the watch of Mr. Harbison and Ms. Upshaw. Now those works are presented in concert. Oct. 10. Weill Recital Hall.

'DIALOGUES OF THE CARMELITES' -- New Yorkers haven't seen a major new production of Poulenc's great opera in a long time, partly because the Met's 1977 staging, by John Dexter, has been such a success. But now the City Opera, which gave the New York stage premiere of the work in 1966, presents a fresh concept by Tazewell Thompson in a production unveiled at the Glimmerglass Opera in 2002. The cast includes the formidable Joyce Castle, and George Manahan conducts. Opens Oct. 12. New York State Theater.

MIKHAIL PLETNEV -- If you're looking for fireworks to kick off your season (as the Great Performers series at Lincoln Center undoubtedly is), this explosive Russian pianist is sure to provide them, even in a relatively subdued program of Bach, Beethoven and Brahms. Oct. 13. Avery Fisher Hall.

'WINTERREISE' -- The recording just arrived from EMI Classics, and it is every bit as eloquent as you might expect. Expect the same from the concert, as the distinctive tenor Ian Bostridge makes his Carnegie Hall recital debut in Schubert's great song cycle. The pianist Leif Ove Andsnes, who follows (or leads) Mr. Bostridge's every nuanced turn on the recording, presents this event to open his season-long Perspectives series at Carnegie. Oct. 16. Carnegie Hall.

DEBORAH VOIGT -- Whatever the physical qualities that offended the Royal Opera in London when it bounced her from a production of ''Ariadne auf Naxos'' last season, this radiant and compelling soprano suffers from no lack of energy and stamina. Here, with the Vancouver Opera, she adds a new role, seemingly a natural, to her repertory: the Marschallin in ''Der Rosenkavalier.'' Soon after, with Daniel Barenboim and the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, she performs Schoenberg's haunting monodrama ''Erwartung'' (Oct. 28-30), and on the night of the last performance, she also dashes to the Lyric Opera of Chicago to take part in a gala concert celebrating the company's 50th anniversary. Then she comes to New York, singing Elisabeth in ''Tannhauser'' at the Met (starting Nov. 18). Between performances, she appears in the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade on the Statue of Liberty float. Next year looks much the same, with no end of gleaming notes and phrases. ''Rosenkavalier'' opens Oct. 16. Vancouver Opera, (604) 683-0222. www.vanopera.bc.ca

ANDRAS SCHIFF -- The pianist plays chamber and solo works by Janacek. Oct. 18, 22, 28. Zankel Hall and Carnegie Hall. A related article is on Page 74.

GEWANDHAUS ORCHESTRA OF LEIPZIG -- When Lincoln Center, for whatever reason, declares it a Brahms season, it's a Brahms season. New Yorkers of a certain age will remember when this orchestra came calling with Brahms under its longtime music director, Kurt Masur. Now, to kick off the series ''The Classical Romantic,'' Herbert Blomstedt, the current music director, conducts the Second and Fourth Symphonies and the two piano concertos in a pair of concerts, with Mikhail Pletnev as, undoubtedly, a commanding soloist. Oct. 18-19. Avery Fisher Hall.

NANCARROW FESTIVAL -- Not content with great Lisztian or Rachmaninoffian handfuls of piano sound, the inventive American Conlon Nancarrow wanted complex patterns that he was sure would elude the grasp of live performers. So he turned to the player piano, imprinting the music onto piano rolls for mechanical reproduction. But the piano duo of Helena Bugallo and Amy Williams has been trying to reclaim some of these pieces for live performance in four-hand arrangements. In the first concert here, they play 12 studies for player piano as well as Stravinsky's duo arrangement of ''The Rite of Spring.'' In three other concerts, the pianist Christopher Taylor and the ensemble Alarm Will Sound will perform much of Nancarrow's music written for live performance as well as pieces by composers who influenced him and whom he influenced. Oct. 21, Nov. 11, Dec. 3, Feb. 19. Miller Theater.

BOSTON SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA -- The venerable ensemble installs a new music director for the first time since 1973. And James Levine announces his presence in a big way, with Mahler's ''Symphony of a Thousand,'' first in Boston (Oct. 22-23), then in New York. Oct. 25. Carnegie Hall.

TOKYO STRING QUARTET -- The group performs works by Schoenberg, Eisler and Zemlinsky. Oct. 23, Feb. 12, May 7. 92nd Street Y. A related article is on Page 79.

ST. PETERSBURG PHILHARMONIC -- With all the publicity accorded Valery Gergiev and the Kirov Orchestra, you might think that this orchestra, with its rich history, had become the B team in St. Petersburg. Don't believe it, at least until you've heard for yourself. Yuri Temirkanov conducts three programs of more or less standard fare. Some very standard: you may think you've heard one too many performances of Tchaikovsky's ''Pathetique'' Symphony. But if you haven't heard Mr. Temirkanov conduct it with this orchestra, you've probably heard one too few. Oct. 26, 27, 29. Carnegie Hall.

'LE GRAND MACABRE' -- The San Francisco Opera gives the American stage premiere of an opera by Gyorgy Ligeti. Opens Oct. 29. War Memorial Opera House, San Francisco, (415) 864-3330. www.sfopera.com. A related article is on Page 73.

HOUSTON GRAND OPERA -- The company celebrates its 50th anniversary in the adventurous style to which it has become accustomed in recent decades, with not one but two premieres (its 31st and 32nd). First comes Daniel Catan's ''Salsipuedes: A Tale of Love, War and Anchovies.'' The audience, the brochure says, perhaps rashly, is invited to dance in the aisles. But there won't be much dancing, at least for the sex-deprived men, in the other new work, opening on March 4: Mark Adamo's ''Lysistrata, or The Nude Goddess.'' ''Salsipuedes'' opens Oct. 29. Wortham Theater Center, Houston, (713) 228-6737. www.hgo.com

'HAROUN AND THE SEA OF STORIES' -- Of all the things Charles Wuorinen's music has been called over the years, ''charming'' probably does not rank near the top. Yet that is precisely the quality that will be needed in his new opera, to match Salman Rushdie's delightful novel and James Fenton's artful libretto. Mr. Rushdie's book, a paean to storytelling, engages the art in manifold ways, using almost everything but music. (And it often comes close there, too.) Mr. Wuorinen now leaps into that breach. Or rather, walks into it, for the piece, featured in a series of readings at the New York City Opera in 2000, has seemed on the verge of completion for years. Part of it, in fact, ''The Haroun Songbook,'' is already available on CD, and the City Opera finally presents the whole of it. Oct. 31. New York State Theater.

ENGLISH CONCERT -- This pioneering period-instrument group, big in the 1970's and 80's, seemed to lose steam toward the end of Trevor Pinnock's tenure as founding director. If anyone can re-energize it, it should be the electrifying violinist Andrew Manze, its new leader. Several Vivaldi concertos will afford ample display of Mr. Manze's virtuosity. The other repertory ranges from the overfamiliar (Mozart's ''Kleine Nachtmusik'') to the obscure (a serenata by Johann Heinrich Schmelzer). Oct. 31. Alice Tully Hall.

November

DANIEL BARENBOIM -- This pianist (and conductor and political provocateur and would-be diplomat) has always been a man in a hurry, and he sometimes sounds it in his new Warner Classics recording of the quintessentially mellow preludes and fugues of Bach's ''Well-Tempered Clavier,'' Book 1. You have to hope that he will relax a bit in this live performance of the work. Nov. 1. Carnegie Hall.

DRESDEN PHILHARMONIC -- Here, a few weeks after the Leipzig Gewandhaus Orchestra concerts, is the other half of Lincoln Center's Brahms team (not to be confused with the better-known Dresden Staatskapelle, which performs Brahms on April 13 at Carnegie Hall under Myung-Whun Chung). Rafael Fruhbeck de Burgos conducts the Dresden Philharmonic in Brahms's First Symphony, Violin Concerto (with Julia Fischer as soloist) and ''German Requiem.'' Nov. 7-8. Avery Fisher Hall.

MUSIC AND DANCE OF THE JEWISH WEDDING -- Here is another key component in the Y's festival, ''Celebrate 350: Jewish Life in America.'' This series of three concerts explores various wedding traditions: first the Ashkenazi, then the Bukharan and the Moroccan. Nov. 10, Dec. 8, Feb. 3. 92nd Street Y.

'IN YOUR EAR' -- This weekend festival, curated by the composer John Adams, features Joshua Redman, on saxophone; Kayhan Kahlor, playing Persian music on the fiddle-like kamancheh; the actress and playwright Anna Deveare Smith, in conversation; and others. Nov. 12-14. Zankel Hall.

STEVE REICH -- The American master and his musicians perform three programs of his music, old and new, including the haunting ''Different Trains.'' (Mr. Reich is also the subject of a Composer Portrait concert featuring So Percussion on March 25 at the Miller Theater.) Nov. 13, Jan. 29, April 2. Metropolitan Museum.

TRIO MEDIAEVAL -- Iraq wasn't the only thing handed over this summer. What's more, the handover of hegemony between female vocal groups in the not always placid world of early music was orderly. Anonymous 4 disbanded after last season and a New York farewell appearance at Corpus Christi Church, where it had performed for years. Now the Oslo-based Trio Mediaeval, which made its New York debut last season, takes over in the church's invaluable series Music Before 1800, performing the 13th-century ''Messe de Tournai'' and other works. (The trio will also appear on April 7 at Merkin Concert Hall.) Nov. 14. Corpus Christi Church, 529 West 121st Street, (212) 666-9266. www.mb1800.org

AMERICAN SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA -- If you have an opinion about Beethoven's pupil Carl Czerny, it is probably not favorable, having been formed when you were force-fed his piano exercises as a child. But for good or ill, there is much more Czerny to be had (as witness the opus number of his Symphony in D presented here, 781). Leon Botstein, in his never-ending quest to right musical wrongs, tries to rehabilitate Czerny with a full program of his music. Nov. 14. Avery Fisher Hall.

MUSICIANS FROM MARLBORO -- This concert series, like the Marlboro Music Festival in Vermont from which it derives, offers a remarkable opportunity to see the torch being passed from veteran artists to gifted younger musicians as they mingle in performance. Nov. 19, Dec. 17, Feb. 25. Metropolitan Museum.

KREMERATA BALTICA -- The superb violinist Gidon Kremer and his crack instrumentalists from the Baltic states play the first of two concerts called ''Shostakovich and After'' -- curiously, since all the music is by Shostakovich. The big works here are the Chamber Symphony (Op. 110a, an expansion of the wrenching Eighth String Quartet) and the equally wrenching Symphony No. 14. Nov. 20, May 3. Carnegie Hall.

'ANDROMEDA LIBERATA' -- You be the judge. Exhibit A is a new Deutsche Grammophon Archiv recording of this operalike serenata, with music by Vivaldi, to be released in early November. The work turned up in 2002, and the first question is how much of the music is by Vivaldi. Scholars are divided. Some say that it is all Vivaldi, others that it is a pastiche to which he contributed in a minor way, much the way Mozart did to ''The Philosopher's Stone,'' unearthed several years ago. The second question is how much it should matter to listeners. Apparently the work is good in its own right. Still, will we insist on putting the cart first, wondering how much we should enjoy the work based on how much is by Vivaldi? Probably. In any case, there will be plenty of evidence to consider. Exhibit B is a live performance of the piece by the musicians who recorded it, Andrea Marcon and the Venice Baroque Orchestra. Nov. 29. Zankel Hall.

'LOST OBJECTS' -- Masterminded and composed by the artistic directors of Bang on a Can, Michael Gordon, David Lang and Julia Wolfe, this purports to be, oxymoronically, a Baroque oratorio for our times. It is described as ''a musical exploration of the meaning of memory,'' a contemplation of ''the grace bestowed upon each thing, person, animal and idea, the ordinary and the not-so-ordinary lost objects of our shared and vanishing culture.'' Well, I guess you have to be there. The army of collaborators includes Deborah Artman, the librettist; Francois Girard, the stage director; DJ Spooky; Concerto Koln, a period-instrument band (but which period?); the New York Virtuoso Singers; and the Bang on a Can Lost Objects Ensemble. Nov. 30, Dec. 2-4. Brooklyn Academy of Music.

'THE OXFORD HISTORY OF WESTERN MUSIC' -- When Richard Taruskin writes a book, he writes a book -- or two, or six. Many who knew that he was writing a Stravinsky book in the 1980's wondered why it was taking so long to come out. When it finally did, in two hefty volumes in 1996, everyone understood why. Mr. Taruskin has since been writing a history of music (while also writing articles for The New York Times, among other publications), and it is about to appear in six hefty volumes. This shapes up as the most important publishing event in classical music since The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians, which appeared in 20 volumes in 1980 and 29 in 2001. But that was a work of many minds (including Mr. Taruskin's); this is the work of one. What's more, it promises to be a good read, more than can be said for vast tracts of New Grove. November. Oxford University Press.

POPOV'S SYMPHONY NO. 1 -- Before Shostakovich's Fourth Symphony (1936), there was Gavril Popov's First (first performed in 1935), seemingly the model for it. Popov was a worthy foil to Shostakovich at the time, and in a new recording, Leon Botstein and the London Symphony pair that First with Shostakovich's early Theme and Variations (Op. 3). November. Telarc.

December

TILL FELLNER -- This gifted young Austrian pianist's visibility rose considerably recently with his engaging ECM recording of Book 1 of Bach's ''Well-Tempered Clavier.'' Here he plays Bach's French Suite No. 5 amid a hefty load of Beethoven. Dec. 1. Zankel Hall.

'RODELINDA' -- Even before the recent boom in Handel operas, this work had a certain currency, its title role providing a vehicle for divas like Joan Sutherland. The Metropolitan Opera, which has never presented it, puts forth its reigning diva, Renee Fleming. But it also adds touches of up-to-date Handel style, including the use of countertenors: excellent ones, Bejun Mehta and David Daniels. Stephen Wadsworth, a Handelian whose ''Xerxes'' was revived last season at the New York City Opera, directs, and Harry Bicket conducts, both in their company debuts. Opens Dec. 2. Metropolitan Opera House.

'THE TRISTAN PROJECT' -- The Los Angeles Philharmonic performs Wagner's opera in concert, interspersed with later music. Dec. 3-5, 10-12. Walt Disney Concert Hall, Los Angeles, (323) 850-2000. www.laphil.com. A related article is on Page 78.

SPHINX ORGANIZATION -- This institution, founded in 1996 and based in Detroit, has done excellent work on behalf of young black and Latino string players, trying to steer them toward positions in orchestras through an annual competition and other programs. Now it comes to New York to show off some of its alumni, as well it should. Dec. 8. Carnegie Hall. www.sphinxmusic.org

'A WEDDING' -- After its success with William Bolcom's ''View From the Bridge'' in 1999, the Lyric Opera returns to the same well. Here Mr. Bolcom bases his work on a Robert Altman movie, and Mr. Altman is on hand to direct. Lauren Flanigan takes the lead role (would she have it any other way?), and Dennis Russell Davies conducts. Opens Dec. 11. Lyric Opera of Chicago, (312) 332-2244. www.lyricopera.org

AULOS ENSEMBLE -- After a couple of years' absence from the Met Museum, this sturdy group of early-music veterans returns with what is typically one of the finest Christmas concerts at the museum, and thus one of the finest in the city. The added presence of the baritone Sanford Sylvan can only enhance the evening. Dec. 13. Metropolitan Museum.

'KATYA KABANOVA' -- The soprano Karita Mattila appears in a revival of Janacek's opera at the Met. Opens Dec. 17. Metropolitan Opera House. A related article is on Page 74.

BEETHOVEN'S NINTH SYMPHONY -- Kurt Masur, who brought many touches of Leipzig tradition to the New York Philharmonic during his tenure as music director, continues to do so as laureate conductor, ringing out the old year with this celebration of brotherhood. Dec. 31. Avery Fisher Hall.

January

'NORTHERN LIGHTS FESTIVAL' -- Neeme Jarvi leads the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra in its annual winter festival of orchestral and chamber concerts and musical discussions, this time concentrating on Finnish and Scandinavian fare. Sibelius dominates, and the major works include his imposing Fifth Symphony, in its seriously undercooked original version, and his Violin Concerto, though not in its original version, equally raw. Pekka Kuusisto is the violinist. Jan. 6-23. New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark, and other locations in New Jersey. www.njsymphony.org

MET ORCHESTRA -- Thematic programming? This is just perverse. After a normal first half (Weber's ''Euryanthe'' Overture and Brahms's Violin Concerto, with Gil Shaham as soloist), all hell breaks loose with the rip-roaring ''Ameriques,'' by Edgard Varese (a Parisian in America): a concert closer if ever there was one. And James Levine follows that with Gershwin's ditzy ''American in Paris.'' Evidently he likes the little joke, because he is ending a Boston Symphony program in Symphony Hall in March with the same odd coupling. Jan. 9. Carnegie Hall.

TAKACS STRING QUARTET -- The first two installments of this group's recording of the 16 Beethoven quartets have received well-earned praise. Here, about the time that the final volume appears from Decca, the players travel the road again, playing all the quartets, though not in chronological order, in six concerts presented by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center. Jan. 9, 11, 21, 23, 28, 30. Alice Tully Hall.

'KAFKA FRAGMENTS' -- As part of her Perspectives series at Carnegie Hall, Dawn Upshaw collaborates with the director Peter Sellars in a staging of a work by Gyorgy Kurtag for soprano and violin. A wild card. Jan. 10, 12, 13. Zankel Hall.

CARNEGIE HALL CHORAL WORKSHOP -- This event, founded in 1990 by Robert Shaw, has pretty much stuck to the mold since Shaw's death in 1999, with nonspecialist conductors picking up where the Shaw acolyte Norman Mackenzie leaves off in preparing the concluding concert. But this year the seasoned choral specialist Helmuth Rilling moves in, undoubtedly with strong ideas of his own about how a chorus (this one larded with choral professionals from around the country) should be prepared. The work at hand is Mozart's unfinished Mass in C minor in the premiere of a new completion by Robert Levin, who has a series of his own, ''Mozart Explored,'' at Carnegie this season. Jan. 10-15. Carnegie Hall.

PAUL O'DETTE -- The lutenist gives a recital as part of Music Before 1800. Jan. 16. Corpus Christi Church, 529 West 121st Street, (212) 666-9266. www.mb1800.org. A related article is on Page 73.

KIROV OPERA -- The stellar company from St. Petersburg, directed by Valery Gergiev, begins a residency in Washington with a ''Kirov Spectacular,'' also involving the Kirov Ballet. Then the opera company presents three performances of Mussorgsky's ''Boris Godunov.'' Jan 18, 19, 22; 21-23. Kennedy Center Opera House.

'BRAHMS THE PROGRESSIVE' -- Lincoln Center may have the franchise on Brahms the Classical Romantic, but the Miller Theater is searching out forward-looking strains in his smaller-scale pieces, juxtaposing them with works of later masters. The programs all look delicious, but the second is of particular note, with the pianist Christopher Taylor joining the Ying Quartet in Brahms's daunting Piano Quintet as well as quintets by Anton Webern and Peter Lieberson. Jan. 21, Feb. 10, March 5, 19, 26. Miller Theater.

LORRAINE HUNT LIEBERSON -- Pick your event with this superb mezzo-soprano. It could be her performance in Berlioz's ''Romeo et Juliette'' with James Levine and the Boston Symphony at Carnegie Hall (Dec. 6). It could be her rendition of Britten's ''Phaedra'' with Colin Davis and the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall (Dec. 16-18). It could be her Carnegie recital debut (May 8). (No repertory announced yet; it hardly matters.) For me, it's sure to be a performance of Mahler's ''Lied von der Erde'' with the tenor Ben Heppner in a concert with Mr. Levine and the Met Orchestra. What beauties may await in the work's ineffably lingering farewell? Nah, don't pick just one. Jan. 23. Carnegie Hall.

CINCINNATI SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA -- Paavo Jarvi, the orchestra's dynamic music director, dutifully supplies an appendage of sorts to his father's ''Northern Lights Festival'' with the New Jersey Symphony, just ended. Or might there be Oedipal rivalry at work? In fact, Paavo, the firebrand of the family, duplicates two works from Neeme Jarvi's festival, Grieg's Piano Concerto (with Lars Vogt as soloist) and Sibelius's Fifth Symphony, and he may just stir greater excitement with them. For good measure, he adds Aulis Sallinen's Symphony No. 8 (''Autumnal Fragments''), in its New York premiere. Jan. 24. Carnegie Hall.

'RENAISSANCE MUSE' -- The stage director Mark Lamos is sure to produce something captivating in this collaboration with the superb countertenor Andreas Scholl in Lincoln Center's acclaimed ''New Visions'' series. Jan. 26, 28, 29. John Jay College Theater, 899 10th Avenue, at 59th Street, (212) 721-6500. www.lincolncenter.org

LONDON SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA -- Pierre Boulez conducts two programs of his music (''Livre Pour Cordes,'' ''Derive 2'') and that of others (Mahler's Fifth Symphony, Stravinsky's Symphonies of Wind Instruments and ''Rite of Spring''). But for many, the most attractive concert may well be the middle one, in which Mr. Boulez discusses ''The Rite of Spring,'' with musical examples played live, then conducts the work complete. Jan. 27-29. Carnegie Hall.

LAHTI SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA -- Osmo Vanska, who just generated great excitement in his first season as music director of the Minnesota Orchestra, visits with the Finnish ensemble that put him on the map. (Or was it the reverse? Or both?) You will probably not hear a more idiomatic reading of a Sibelius symphony this season than the performance of the Second here. The program also includes Tchaikovsky's Third Piano Concerto and Prokofiev's First, with Louis Lortie as soloist. Jan. 30. Avery Fisher Hall.

CARLOS KLEIBER -- Although he hadn't been very active in recent years, this conductor's death in July came as a shock to the music world, abruptly closing out the possibility that he might someday emerge from seclusion and go out in a blaze of glory with a spate of performances and new recordings. So we are left with what we have -- almost. What we have is about to include six new DVD's and a VHS cassette of Kleiber performances, some never before released, and it is a special joy to see as well as hear this magnetic maestro in action. January. Deutsche Grammophon and Philips.

February

CLEVELAND ORCHESTRA -- There is seldom any additional incentive needed to bestir oneself for the splendid Cleveland Orchestra. But here is also a chance to hear Radu Lupu play all five Beethoven piano concertos. Franz Welser-Most surrounds them with a wild array of works, from Schubert's Eighth Symphony (''Unfinished'') to Roy Harris's Third, Shostako-vich's Eleventh (''The Year 1905'') and Henri Dutilleux's Second (''Le Double''); from Berg's Three Pieces for Orchestra (Op. 6) to Harrison Birtwistle's ''Night's Black Bird.'' Feb. 1, 2, 4, 5. Carnegie Hall.

NATIONAL SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA -- Having opened the season with a gala celebration of the 60th birthday of its music director, Leonard Slatkin, the orchestra mounts a minifestival, ''A New America: The 1940's and the Arts,'' part of a larger undertaking by the Kennedy Center. It offers two programs of music by Barber, Bernstein, Copland, Korngold, Schuman and others. (By this time, on Jan. 20-22, Mr. Slatkin will have demonstrated his continuing commitment to new American music with the premiere of Philip Glass's Symphony No. 7, commissioned by the orchestra.) Feb. 3-5, 10-12. Kennedy Center Concert Hall.

RICCARDO CHAILLY -- In his last years with the Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra of Amsterdam, an ensemble with a great Mahler tradition, Mr. Chailly was becoming a formidable Mahlerian. Now, in the first of his two weeks with the New York Philharmonic, an orchestra with its own personal connection to the composer, he conducts Mahler's Seventh Symphony. (Beforehand, in November, Decca is to release a new Chailly recording of Mahler's Ninth with the Concertgebouw Orchestra.) Feb. 10, 11, 12, 15. Avery Fisher Hall.

RICCARDO MUTI -- The former maestro of the Philadelphia Orchestra returns for only the second time since his departure in 1992 and for the first time since the orchestra moved to its new home in the Kimmel Center in 2001. And he does so for a single benefit concert to help reduce the orchestra's deficit, responding to a request by the players rather than management. Economic circumstances weigh heavily on the minds of the musicians at the moment, as they negotiate a new contract. The gap between what management is offering and what the players are demanding is said to be considerable. Feb. 13. Kimmel Center for the Performing Arts, Philadelphia, (215) 893-1999. www.philorch.org

JOSE VAN DAM -- To judge from recent appearances here, there is every reason to believe that this veteran Belgian bass-baritone is still singing with the best of them. The first program consists of French songs; the second, lieder by Schubert and Schumann. Feb. 13, 16. Alice Tully Hall.

EMERSON STRING QUARTET -- This splendid group goes from strength to strength, generally concentrating on one composer at a time, while adding context or contrast. Here, in a four-concert series, ''A Vision of Mendelssohn,'' the context consists of works by Bach, Schubert and Schumann. To end the series, the St. Lawrence String Quartet joins the Emerson in a performance of Mendelssohn's Octet. But in a new recording of the octet -- included in a CD set of the complete string quartets, to be released in February by Deutsche Grammophon -- the Emerson players overdub with the aid of a computer, performing all eight lines. Feb. 15, March 22, April 5 and 19. Zankel Hall.

'A MIDSUMMER NIGHT'S DREAM' -- Not just Mendelssohn's incidental music but a substantial representation of Shakespeare's play. Not just once but twice in close succession. Here the accent is English, as Ivan Fischer (well, a Hungarian, but no matter) conducts the London-based Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment, and Tim Carroll directs actors including some from the Globe Theater in London. Then, on March 17, 18, 19 and 22, to open the New York Philharmonic's festival ''Visions of the Beyond'' at Avery Fisher Hall, Neville Marriner conducts the orchestra and Edward Berkeley directs. Age of Enlightenment performance, Feb. 24. Alice Tully Hall.

March

LORIN MAAZEL -- The New York Philharmonic celebrates the 75th birthday of its music director with a concert of his own music. Though not well known as a composer in these parts, Mr. Maazel is not wholly unfamiliar. One work here, Music for Cello and Orchestra, he conducted with the Bavarian Radio Symphony, and with Mstislav Rostropovich as soloist, at Carnegie Hall in 1996, and it's a good one. How the music stands up in quantity (five works in the program) remains to be seen. March 1. Avery Fisher Hall.

NEW YORK COLLEGIUM -- Andrew Parrott has greatly improved the quality of this early-music group in his two-and-a-half seasons as music director. He has also propagated the suddenly stylish notion of how Bach's choral works would have been performed in his time: basically one voice to a part; not a chorus at all, as we usually think of it. Here he applies that practice to Bach's most monumental creation, the ''St. Matthew Passion.'' One hopes that it will prove an attractive alternative, because for some of us who love terrific massed choral singing, it will probably never be more than an alternative. March 3-4. Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue at 84th Street, (212) 717-9246. www.nycollegium.org

VIENNA PHILHARMONIC -- No orchestra can play the Germanic classics with greater depth and commitment than this one. But because of the very distinctiveness of its Middle European sound and because, as basically an opera orchestra, it plays a limited symphonic repertory, it can seem out of its element in only slightly more exotic fare. Eleven years ago at Carnegie Hall, even the fierce exertions of Georg Solti failed to evoke the incisiveness and harshness needed in Shostakovich's Fifth Symphony. Perhaps the Latvian conductor Mariss Jansons will supply the requisite Slavic touch in that work. Sibelius's First Symphony may be less problematic, and the rest of the works here should provide pure pleasure and edification: Beethoven's Second Symphony, Brahms's First, Mahler's First and Schoenberg's ''Verklarte Nacht.'' March 11-13. Carnegie Hall.

SAN FRANCISCO SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA -- Michael Tilson Thomas's and Leif Ove Andsnes's Perspectives series at Carnegie Hall intersect in a performance of Rachmaninoff's Second Piano Concerto in the first program. Other works include Mahler's Seventh Symphony, Shostakovich's Fifteenth and Mr. Thomas's own ''Poems of Emily Dickinson.'' March 16-17, Carnegie Hall.

EMANUEL AX AND YEFIM BRONFMAN -- The piano duo version of Stravinsky's ''Rite of Spring'' must live vividly in memory for anyone who saw Leonard Bernstein almost elbow Michael Tilson Thomas off the bench in a supercharged performance at Alice Tully Hall in 1981. The two star pianists here are sure to make the work (along with music of Ravel and Debussy) compelling and memorable in their own right. March 16. Avery Fisher Hall.

LE JARDIN DES VOIX -- William Christie, the American who has galvanized the early-music scene in Paris in recent decades, tends his own vocal garden, Les Arts Florissants, meticulously. Now he looks to young shoots, singers selected from major conservatories by audition, presenting them in Baroque music. You can bank on his discernment. March 16-17. Alice Tully Hall.

'VISIONS OF THE BEYOND' -- Berlioz's ''Damnation of Faust'' and Liszt's ''Faust Symphony,'' maybe. Perhaps even Mendelssohn's ''Midsummer Night's Dream.'' But what do those works and Bach's ''Art of Fugue,'' Janacek's Sinfonietta and Gyorgy Ligeti's ''Atmospheres'' all have in common? Very little, it would seem, except that they are all part of a monthlong New York Philharmonic festival whose concept is not exactly transparent: something to do with a blending of man, nature and the immortal, according to the press release. The title, at least, comes from another entry, Messiaen's powerful ''Eclairs sur l'Au-Dela.'' Undoubtedly all will come clear. March 17-April 16. Avery Fisher Hall.

'ORLANDO' -- With the sturdy countertenor Bejun Mehta in the title role, chances are good that the New York City Opera will continue its run of successes in Handel operas. Amy Burton and Jennifer Aylmer also appear in this new production, directed by Chas Rader-Shieber. Opens March 20. New York State Theater.

April

BORODIN QUARTET -- Not many chamber groups survive to celebrate their 60th anniversary. Prospects are good for the Juilliard String Quartet, in 2006 (without, of course, any of its original members). But the Borodin Quartet reaches the wire first, celebrating its six decades with vintage scores by Tchaikovsky, Stravinsky and Shostakovich. (The group's first cellist was Mstislav Rostropovich, who has gone on to bigger things.) April 2. 92nd Street Y.

KIROV ORCHESTRA -- We have a good idea what to expect from Valery Gergiev and his band in Russian music: in this case, Tchaikovsky's ''Francesca da Rimini,'' the Mussorgsky-Ravel ''Pictures at an Exhibition,'' Borodin's Second Symphony, Rimsky-Korsakov's ''Capriccio Espagnol'' and Prokofiev's First Piano Concerto and Second Symphony. And the Finnish Sibelius (Violin Concerto, Seventh Symphony) is close to their home in St. Petersburg. But what about Mahler? It should be fascinating to find out in the final program, the ''Resurrection'' Symphony, with Irina Mataeva and Olga Borodina as the vocal soloists. April 4-6. Carnegie Hall.

'PULLING STRINGS: VIOLINISTS ON FILM' -- Great Performers at Lincoln Center provides one of its patented wide-ranging film surveys, including performance clips large and small, featuring almost every past violinist that you've heard of and some that you haven't, as well as documentary material. April 5-19. Walter Reade Theater, 165 West 65th Street, (212) 721-6500. www.lincolncenter.org

'WAR REQUIEM' -- Osmo Vanska, the music director of the Minnesota Orchestra, conducts that ensemble in a rare collaboration with the St. Paul Chamber Orchestra in Britten's great work, in each orchestra's hall. The vocal soloists are Helen Donath, James Taylor and Hakan Hagegard. April 7-8. Orchestra Hall, Minneapolis, (800) 292-4141. www.minnesotaorchestra.org. April 9. Ordway Center, St. Paul, (651) 291-1144. www.thespco.org

OLGA BORODINA -- The Temple of Dendur at the Met Museum may not be the best place to hear this or any other vocalist in songs. On the other hand, where wouldn't you want to hear Ms. Borodina? To clinch the case, she sings Tchaikovsky and Rachmaninoff. April 9. Metropolitan Museum.

'LES PECHEURS DE PERLES' -- In addition to ''Carmen'' in March, the New York City Opera offers ''the'' other opera by Bizet, ''The Pearl Fishers'' for the first time since 1991. In a new production by Andrew Sinclair, Mary Dunleavy sings Leila and Emmanuel Plasson conducts. Opens April 10. New York State Theater.

JORDI SAVALL -- This conductor and master of the viola da gamba is a major force in the international early-music scene, and his colorful and often daring recordings for the Spanish label Alia Vox are always exciting. Here he appears with three groups that he leads, Hesperion XXI, La Capella Reial de Catalunya and Le Concert des Nations, in programs of mostly Baroque music. April 11, 13, 18. Metropolitan Museum.

OLGA KERN -- This Russian pianist, who shared the gold medal at the Van Cliburn International Piano Competition in 2001, seems with time to have emerged as the clear winner. She stood out when the foundation presented the four finalists last spring at Zankel Hall, and she gave her Carnegie Hall debut immediately after, substituting for an ailing Krystian Zimerman. Here she kicks off a series of six recitals with other piano competition winners: Severin von Eckardstein (Queen Elisabeth competition in Brussels), Boris Giltburg (Vendome in France), Alexei Grynyuk (Shanghai youth competition), Giuseppe Albanese (Vendome) and Antti Siirala (Dublin and Leeds). Proponents and opponents of musical competitions will surely find much to wrangle about here. April 14-17. Metropolitan Museum.

ST. LOUIS SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA -- All eyes and ears are on the orchestra's music director to be (next year), David Robertson, as a star in a new generation of American conductors. This program is all American, with works of Ives (including the Second Symphony), Copland and John Adams. April 16. Carnegie Hall.

'FAUST' -- Roberto Alagna has had almost as many misadventures as triumphs at the Metropolitan Opera, since his debut in 1996 ran aground on ''fourth tenor'' hype. The title role in Gounod's opera should suit him well in this new production, and he is surrounded by fine singers, including Soile Isokoski, Dmitri Hvorostovsky and Rene Pape. Andrei Serban directs, replacing the originally announced Elijah Moshinsky, and James Levine conducts. Opens April 21. Metropolitan Opera House.

May

NEW YORK FESTIVAL OF SONG -- The group repeats one of its most popular programs, ''Lost Tribes of Vaudeville,'' exploring the cultures of Jewish and black vaudeville, with composers ranging from Irving Berlin to Eubie Blake and singers including LaChanze and Darius de Haas. May 11. Merkin Concert Hall. www.nyfos.org

'CYRANO DE BERGERAC' -- Metropolitan Opera audiences may vaguely know of Franco Alfano from his 15 or so minutes of fame, as the composer who finished the third act of ''Turandot,'' left incomplete at Puccini's death in 1924. Now adventurous Met-goers can hear a complete Alfano opera, from 1936. (Few are likely to remember the Met's presentation of Alfano's ''Madonna Imperia'' in 1928.) Francesca Zambello directs the new ''Cyrano,'' a collaboration with the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, and Placido Domingo will work around the title character's big nose without, you have to hope, sounding unduly nasal. The Met offers just three performances, clearly hedging its bets on how adventurous its patrons may be, even given the draw of Mr. Domingo. (In contrast, the Met's production of ''Turandot,'' which opens on Jan. 3, runs for 14 performances, until May 5.) ''Cyrano'' opens May 13. Metropolitan Opera House.

CHICAGO SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA -- Daniel Barenboim, the orchestra's music director, leads off with an odd coupling: Bach's quirky Second Orchestral Suite, with Mathieu Dufour as flute soloist, and Mahler's agonized Ninth Symphony. For the rest, in a fine bit of symmetry, Mr. Barenboim plays piano in a performance of Bartok's First Concerto in a program conducted by Pierre Boulez and conducts Mr. Boulez's ''Notations'' in a second program of his own. Mr. Boulez adds Bartok's Concerto for Orchestra and Four Pieces (Op. 12); Mr. Barenboim, Beethoven's Seventh Symphony and the Adagio from Mahler's Tenth. May 13-15. Carnegie Hall.

VAN CLIBURN INTERNATIONAL PIANO COMPETITION -- What to make of this event, which has so often produced winners who have quickly sunk into oblivion? At the last outing, in 2001, it had a genuine talent on its hands, and to judge from concerts given by all the medalists last spring at Zankel Hall, a clear-cut winner in Olga Kern. But it split the gold medal between her and Stanislav Ioudenitch. Can anyone here play this game? May 20-June 5. Bass Performance Hall, Fort Worth, (817) 738-6536. www.cliburn.org

JONATHAN NOTT -- This British conductor makes his New York debut in a big way. First, with the Bamberg Symphony and in combination with the brilliant pianist Pierre-Laurent Aimard, he offers two concerts devoted to Beethoven, Mahler and Gyorgy Ligeti. May 6, 8. Avery Fisher Hall. Then, with the Ensemble Intercontemporain in the main hall of the new Jazz at Lincoln Center complex at Columbus Circle, he conducts more Ligeti, a work by Wolfgang Rihm and an evening devoted to Benedict Mason's ''ChaplinOperas,'' with music to three silent films. May 24-25. Rose Theater, Broadway at 60th Street, (212) 721-6500. www.lincolncenter.org

LOS ANGELES OPERA -- ''A film adaptation of 'Sweeney Todd' is now in preproduction,'' the company announced a few months ago, ''and all theatrical performance rights have been retracted.'' So your ''Sweeney Todd'' production has collapsed, and you have the ebullient baritone Bryn Terfel committed to dates that are suddenly open. What do you do? Happily, you are able to pull a revival of Verdi's ''Falstaff'' out of the hat, and the title role happens to be a Terfel speciality. (In fact, he will just have sung it at the Houston Grand Opera, from April 28 to May 15.) Whew! Opens May 28. Dorothy Chandler Pavilion, Los Angeles, (213) 972-8001. www.laopera.com

June

QATSI TRILOGY -- Some of us think that Philip Glass's scores for Godfrey Reggio's high-minded films ''Koyaanisqatsi,'' ''Naqoyqatsi'' and ''Powaqqatsi'' are among his better work. And some of us, often the same people, think that Mr. Glass's scores may be the best parts of those earnest and simplistic films. Here is an opportunity to test those premises, as Mr. Glass performs the music with his ensemble to accompany the films. June 2-4. Rose Theater, Broadway at 60th Street, (212) 721-6500. www.lincolncenter.org

LOS ANGELES PHILHARMONIC -- By all reports, Avery Fisher Hall must seem a comedown after the Walt Disney Concert Hall in Los Angeles, but Esa-Pekka Salonen and the orchestra will presumably cope in two programs of works by Ravel, Stravinsky, Shostakovich and John Adams. June 3, 5. Avery Fisher Hall.

OPERA ORCHESTRA OF NEW YORK -- This company has made a specialty of concert presentations of operas that are seldom presented in opera houses. In some cases you understand the neglect. In the case of Weber's ''Freischutz,'' you don't (or at least, I don't). Eve Queler conducts a performance with Charlotte Margiono, in her American debut, as Agathe and Johan Botha as Max. (But why Puccini's ''Fanciulla del West'' in a season when the New York City Opera is mounting a new production?) ''Freischutz,'' June 6. Carnegie Hall.

MAHLER'S SIXTH SYMPHONY -- Lorin Maazel ended each of his first two seasons as music director of the New York Philharmonic resoundingly, with a Mahler Symphony. But the two works so far -- the Second and the Third -- made for triumphal farewells. Best not to read anything into the fact that Mr. Maazel and the orchestra end this season on a tragic note, with the pulverizing Sixth Symphony. June 22-25. Avery Fisher Hall.
 Compiled with the assistance of BEN SISARIO

HEADLINE: Baseball's Origins: They Ain't Found Till They're Found

BYLINE: By BILL PENNINGTON

 BODY:
Textbooks once unequivocally stated that baseball was invented in Cooperstown, N.Y., in 1839, and provided as proof the picture of a dusty, ripped old ball pulled from an attic trunk. It turned out to be a hoax, baseball's first hidden-ball trick.
 The next official version put the origin in Hoboken, N.J., in 1846. That story stood until 2001, when a librarian found two 1823 newspaper references to ''base ball'' games in Lower Manhattan. Then in May, a clerk walked out of a library vault in Pittsfield, Mass., waving a faded ordinance from 1791 that banned the playing of baseball within 80 yards of the big church in the town square.
 Baseball history had a new king in the eternal run home. 
 Until the next discovery usurps Pittsfield, moving baseball's birthplace to another state or era, or both. Which raises the question: How come history can say what John Adams had for lunch on Jan. 24, 1776 (wild goose on a spit), but baseball cannot pinpoint its genesis within hundreds of years or thousands of miles?
 When it comes to baseball, there is no agreement on which century the first game was played. It could have been the 18th century; it could have been the 13th century. There is some record of each.
 There is no agreement on which continent baseball was invented either. Was it North America, Europe or Africa? There is some evidence for all three.
 Historians know more, for sure, about games played in 776 B.C. than they do about the first time someone hit a ball back, back, back, then broke into a preening trot.
 They know more about how Roman gladiators decided who would be first in line marching into the Colosseum than they do about the first time someone made up a baseball lineup, thereby entering the first arena of grandstand second-guessing.
 Recent best-selling biographies have laid bare the most copious details of the American past: Adams liked a nip of hard cider before breakfast; Franklin spent an hour each day nude in his chambers with the windows open; George Washington walked four miles a night.
 ''With a sport like baseball, which so reveres stats and its past,'' the historian Doris Kearns Goodwin said, ''you would think that this major stat of the past would be the crown jewel to find. Baseball, after all, is the ultimate sport of figures and dates. The origin of the game is the fabulous treasure.''
 But as hot as the baseball birthplace trail may be, few believe the quest is heading into the final innings. Baseball history, in fact, may forevermore be unconstrained by age.
 ''People ask: when was the first baseball game?'' said John Thorn, the baseball historian who uncovered the existence of the Pittsfield ordinance during a middle-of-the-night Internet search. ''It may be an unanswerable question. That's what makes it eternally fascinating.''
 Tom Shieber, the curator of new media at the National Baseball Hall of Fame in Cooperstown, said: ''The answer to the question is philosophical, like an archeologist wondering when man is man. We know there were ballgames going back many centuries. There is a reference to the Pilgrims at Plymouth Rock playing ball. But was it baseball as we know it? And what is that?''
 Ted Spencer, the Hall of Fame's longtime curator, added another perspective.
 ''Did you know the Pittsfield ordinance also bans a bunch of other sports, including football?'' Spencer said. ''Did you know nobody cares? But they care that it mentioned baseball. I got calls from reporters all over the country. That's because baseball has a spiritual hold on the American public.''
 The most commonly accepted thesis is that baseball has no specific starting date or place of invention. The game, they say, evolved over time. ''Sprouting like a field of dandelions in the America of the late 1700's,'' Thorn said. Mr. Thorn pointed to the Pittsfield ordinance as evidence that baseball was rampant in 1791. ''They wouldn't have had to ban it to protect the new windows of the new meeting house if it wasn't already a nuisance to that building or others,'' he said.
 And although proud Pittsfield officials have taken to calling their economically waning city ''baseball's Garden of Eden,'' there is an acknowledgement that the city's time in the spotlight of baseball history may be transitory.
 ''The towns east of us in Massachusetts are older, and so are the towns south of us,'' said Dave Potts, a lifelong Pittsfield resident and local baseball historian. ''I'm sure they have good records. It will just take time for someone to find a reference to baseball in those files.''
 Piece by piece, baseball's historical research may progress in this manner for decades, especially as more and more records become available via the Internet. Still, it does lead to the same fundamental questions: Why has baseball's earliest history been so undiscovered? Why is it that the minutiae of the lives of celebrated American pioneers are so public --Ben Franklin failed math as a 9-year-old -- but until recently, little was done to trace baseball before 1823?
 ''Because the daily lives of prominent leaders in the American colonies were deemed important and someone wrote the details down,'' Mr. Shieber, the Hall of Fame's new media curator, said. ''But the games were child's play and often regarded as a wasteful use of time. They weren't documented in the same way.''
 Ms. Goodwin agreed that there have been stages to historical writing and research, with the first stage focusing on the conspicuous historical figures. ''But since then, people have been able to recreate the more unrecorded histories, like slave history and women's history,'' she said. ''So it's not that it is not there to be found. It takes concerted effort, in diaries and letters and writings.''
 David Block, a retired systems analyst and amateur baseball historian, maintained that academic scholarship into the origins of baseball had been lacking until recently.
 ''The research had long been dominated by myth and misconception,'' said Mr. Block, whose book ''Baseball Before We Knew It'' is to be published in January. ''Look at the Abner Doubleday story in Cooperstown. It never happened.''
 Placing the origin of baseball in Cooperstown in 1839 was the work of a turn-of-the-century commission empowered by A.B. Spalding, the sporting goods magnate, who manipulated the commission's findings to ensure the sport had, in his words at the time, ''an American dad.'' That became Doubleday, a Civil War officer, who was supposed to have laid out the first baseball diamond in a Cooperstown dirt field.
 In the latter half of the 20th century, this tale was wholly discredited, especially because Doubleday may have never set foot in Cooperstown. But by then there was a thriving, beloved Hall of Fame in Cooperstown.
 The current wave of baseball researchers now focus their energy not on Cooperstown, but on debunking other myths, like the long-held belief that baseball evolved from the English game of rounders.
 Mr. Block, for example, said he has evidence not only that baseball is older than rounders, but also that baseball originated in England. He cited seven references to baseball in 18th-century English documents, and he said he had found a book written in German in 1796 that refers to ''English baseball.''
 ''They give rules of the game and it starts with a pitcher serving the ball to a batter,'' Mr. Block said. ''The batter has three tries to put the ball in play. The batter runs around something like bases. It defies reason that there isn't some linkage between baseball and the game they are describing.''
 The small gaggle of professional baseball historians relish each of these tidbits as they are unearthed, but some are past the point of being surprised. Inside the Hall of Fame, Mr. Spencer, the curator, pointed to a reproduction hanging on a wall. It is a drawing from Spain in 1251 of people playing a game.
 ''There's a bat and there's a ball,'' Mr. Spencer said, looking at the drawing. ''It looks like two guys playing baseball to me.''
 Not far away is another faint reproduction of an Egyptian wall inscription: pharaohs perhaps engaged in another baseball game.
 Some historians are optimistic that baseball's starting point will eventually be nailed down.
 ''In the last five years, we've moved the date of documented evidence back from 1846 to 1791, which is huge,'' Mr. Thorn, who discovered the Pittsfield ordinance, said. ''And we keep finding more clues. There is the evidence that has been cited from the Plymouth Plantation. The prospect of lassoing the origin of baseball more closely is good. Just because we don't have box scores and baseball cards from a team called the Pilgrims at Plymouth Rock doesn't mean baseball wasn't happening there.''
 Perhaps there is some link there, and finding baseball's origin will now become a popular crusade, a sister cause to Americans' recent fascination with their historical forefathers.
 ''I guess the searching could go in any direction,'' Ms. Goodwin said, ''though it's hard to imagine John Adams playing baseball. But you never know.''
 You never know. Sort of like the baseball history version of Yogi Berra's ''It ain't over till it's over.''
 On Page 31 of David McCullough's biography ''John Adams,'' Adams describes in his diary his idyllic boyhood activities: ''making and sailing boats'' and ''swimming, skating, flying kites and shooting marbles, bat and ball.''
 John Adams was born in 1735.
 So there.

 CORRECTION:
An article on Sunday about the origins of baseball misstated the middle initial of a sporting-goods entrepreneur who helped create a commission in the early 20th century to determine when and where baseball was invented. He was A.G. Spalding, not A.B.

SECTION: Section 2; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk; THE NEW SEASON/ARCHITECTURE; Pg. 97

LENGTH: 1432 words

HEADLINE: Buildings Fit For a Parliament And a President

BYLINE: By NICOLAI OUROUSSOFF

 BODY:

September

COOPER UNION, NEW YORK -- The Santa Monica, Calif., firm Morphosis has built an international reputation with projects like the 1999 Diamond Ranch High School, in Pomona, Calif., whose fragmented corrugated-metal forms evoke a landscape that is breaking apart. Morphosis' design for Cooper Union's new academic building at Astor Place represents its first foray into Manhattan. The design, which will replace the school's 1908 Hewitt building, should bring a touch of Los Angeles irreverence to downtown New York. School officials plan to unveil the plan tomorrow. www.cooper.edu

'CIVIC SPIRIT: CHANGING THE COURSE OF FEDERAL DESIGN' -- A look at the federal government's Excellence in Architecture program, which was started in 1994 to raise the abysmal quality of architecture in government building design. The program's results have not always been stellar, but there are works of genuine architectural interest here, including Richard Meier's United States Courthouse building in Islip, N.Y., Antoine Predock's courthouse in El Paso, Tex., and Smith-Miller & Hawkinson's border station in Champlain, N.Y. Tomorrow-Nov. 10. Center for Architecture, New York. (212) 683-0023. www.aiany.org

ARCHITECTURAL BIENNIAL BEIJING 2004 -- The first in that city, the Beijing Biennial covers a spectacular array of projects, many scheduled for completion in time for the 2008 Olympic Games. Among them are the kind of colossal urban planning schemes that have made China one of the most vital centers of architectural experimentation in the world. And then there are major projects by luminaries like Rem Koolhaas, Herzog & de Meuron and Zaha Hadid. But the real reason to see the show is the spotlight it will cast on a rising generation of Chinese architectural talents like Yung Ho Chang, Ai Weiwei, Liu Jiakun and Zhang Lei. Trained in the years immediately following the cultural revolution, they offer a peek into China's future. Sept. 20-Oct. 6. China National Art Museum, Beijing. www.abbeijing.com/eindex.htm

NATIONAL MUSEUM OF THE AMERICAN INDIAN, WASHINGTON -- The museum, which is part of the Smithsonian, stands on a prominent site on the Washington Mall just in front of the Capitol. Douglas Cardinal, the architect originally hired to design the project, conceived it as a composition of curvaceous forms that would contrast with the hard-edge limestone of Washington's traditional civic buildings. But the Smithsonian fired Mr. Cardinal in 1998. Mr. Cardinal was replaced by a team of architectural consultants that includes John Paul Jones, the Native American Design Collaborative and the Polshek Partnership. The result, according to Mr. Cardinal, is a serious compromise of the design's integrity. The museum opens Sept. 21. (202) 633-1000. www.americanindian.si.edu

'IMPORT/EXPORT: POSTWAR MODERNISM IN AN EXPANDING WORLD, 1945-75' -- Both the theme and location of Docomomo's eighth international conference, which will be held at Columbia University, could not be more timely. The group was originally founded in Holland to protect Modernist landmarks from the wrecking ball. As it has grown, however, Docomomo's mission has become more nuanced: to explore the uneasy relationship between Modernism's disdain for the past and the desire to preserve it. New York is still struggling to come to terms with such issues, as could be seen in the recent battle to save Eero Saarinen's 1960's-era T.W.A. terminal at Kennedy International Airport. Sept. 26-29. (212) 721-9502. Early registration closes on Wednesday and costs $370 for nonmembers. www.docomomo2004.org

CALTRANS DISTRICT 7 HEADQUARTERS, LOS ANGELES -- Another design by Morphosis, this one built. The 1.1 million-square-foot structure is the latest addition to a growing list of high-profile building projects in downtown Los Angeles that already includes Frank Gehry's Walt Disney Concert Hall and Jose Rafael Moneo's Cathedral of Our Lady of the Angels. But with a towering, perforated metal facade that looms over City Hall, the design speaks as much of the California transit authority's role in shaping the identity of Los Angeles as of the city's cultural enlightenment. The opening ceremony is scheduled for Sept. 27.

AL-AZHAR PARK, CAIRO -- This vast 74-acre park in downtown Cairo is one of the most spectacular urban renewal projects in the Middle East; a massive urban dump is being transformed into the city's largest green space. The boldness of the scheme, however, lies in its social mission. Conceived by the Aga Khan Trust for Culture, its aim is to combine thoughtful design and historic preservation with a broader economic program in an effort to revive one of the city's poorest neighborhoods. Architecture and preservation, in other words, are regarded as more than aesthetic issues; they become critical tools in the reshaping of a culture's social fabric. The park will be opened at a ceremony on Sept. 29.

October

'JOSEF AND ANNI ALBERS: DESIGNS FOR LIVING' -- This show traces the couple's long and prolific careers from their early years at the Bauhaus to their later work as part of a wave of emigres who helped carry the Modernist torch to America. It will also take a close look at the creative relationship between the talented husband-and-wife team, who produced a wide array of classic modern designs -- from furniture to textiles and greeting cards -- and who rarely collaborated on artistic ventures. Oct. 1-Feb. 27. Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum, New York. (212) 849-8400.www.cooperhewitt.org

'GLAMOUR' -- Opulence is no longer a naughty word. Or at least that is the message behind an eclectic show at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art. The show looks at how the notion of glamour is reflected in fashion, architecture and industrial design from the 1950's to today. Among the various objects and buildings exhibited will be a 1965 Jaguar E-type Coupe, Edward Durell Stone's 1954 design for the American Embassy in New Delhi, a 1992 ''Cowboy'' corset and chaps by Thierry Mugler, Mark Newsome's 1994 molded plastic chair and Herzog & de Meuron's 2003 Prada shop in Tokyo. Glamour fades, so expect some drearier examples as well. Oct. 9-Jan. 17. San Francisco Museum of Modern Art. (415) 357-4000. www.sfmoma.org

SCOTTISH PARLIAMENT BUILDING, EDINBURGH -- The Spanish architect Enric Miralles's $773 million monument has been attacked for its inflated budget and long construction delays, but it may also offer striking evidence of what architecture lost when he died of a brain tumor four years ago at 45. Miralles said the design was inspired by the small upturned fishing boats that line the Scottish coastline. The building's gently undulating concrete forms make it the most unusual work of architecture built in Scotland in at least a generation. Opening Oct. 9. www.scottish.parliament.uk

LES HALLES, PARIS -- The 1969 demolition of Victor Baltard's famed glass-and-iron pavilions, which housed the city's food halls, is still considered one of the greatest architectural disasters in Parisian history. A decade later, the halls were replaced by the Forum, an underground shopping mall that seemed to point to the city's gradual cultural demise. Now a competition sponsored by the French government seeks to rectify that urban atrocity. The list of architects includes Rem Koolhaas, Jean Nouvel, MVRDV/Winy Maas and David Mangin. City officials plan to announce a winner sometime in October. The selection is likely to stir up old ghosts, sparking more controversy and debate. Designs can be seen at: www.projetleshalles.com

November

WILLIAM J. CLINTON PRESIDENTIAL CENTER, LITTLE ROCK, ARK. -- The main feature of the center, set at the edge of the Arkansas River, is a 400-foot-long museum propped up on slender steel columns. The museum is meant to echo a series of old industrial bridges that span the river. Polshek Partnership, which designed the complex, has said the museum's form also acts as a metaphorical bridge to the 21st century. Architecturally, it embodies the progressive values of an earlier era. Mr. Clinton is scheduled to open the center on Nov. 18.
www.clintonpresidentialcenter.org

December

WHITNEY WATERWORKS TREATMENT FACILITY, NEW HAVEN -- A rare venture by a celebrated architect into the world of large-scale public works. Instead of a conventional stucco-clad shed, Steven Holl designed a structure whose curvaceous metal form evokes an apparition from another world. Set in a residential suburb not far from Yale, it is a testament to the level of invention that can be attained when the property values of academics and architects are at risk.

HEADLINE: Farewell to Pets, and to Free Breakfast?

BYLINE: By AMY GUNDERSON

 BODY:
RYAN SHERMAN doesn't mince words with apartment hunters. ''When I take a client out, I prepare them for the worst,'' said Mr. Sherman, a broker and executive vice president at Century 21 William B. May. Gone are the days when his clients could look at apartments and have a day to mull over the options. Now he insists that they come armed with bank statements, investment account information, a letter from their employer, at least two personal references and, most important, a checkbook.
 There is a new sense of urgency in the rental market, a marked change from earlier this year when the market was soft and some landlords were dangling a month's free rent and payment of broker fees to fill vacancies. ''Four months ago it might take two weeks, but now I can rent something in three days,'' said Peter Polow Jr., chief executive of P & G Equities, a development company that owns eight Manhattan buildings. 
 The rental market appears to have become tighter because there are simply more people hunting. With the economy improving, there are more corporate relocations, and with apartment prices high, there are more people who figure they just can't buy. In some cases, owners are selling so they can cash in on the high prices, and they are also looking for apartments to rent. ''The sales side of the market has really driven the rental market,'' said Scott Stewart, a vice president at the Corcoran Group. 
 As the rental market gets tougher, prime places, especially those below 23rd Street, don't remain available for very long. ''In midsummer, around July, we saw the inventory tighten up significantly,'' said Daren W. Hornig, chief executive of the Quest Group, which runs Dwelling Quest, a residential real estate brokerage firm. ''It is almost a race to get the apartment and get the application in.'' 
 Or as Chris Devilleneuve, a broker with Citi Habitats in the Upper East Side office, put it, ''It is almost like sales now.'' 
 Avnish Patel's apartment search spanned two and a half months, seven real estate brokers, 35 apartments and several weeks of sleeping on a friend's couch. ''There wasn't the availability that I expected -- it was a real painful process,'' said Mr. Patel, who eventually landed a one-bedroom apartment in Chelsea. ''A few of the places had other applicants. Real estate agents would say, 'If it's not you, it's the next guy in an hour.' ''
 Landlords who have not had multiple applicants for apartments since 2000 once again have the luxury of choice. ''A lot of landlords are comparing applicants,'' said Gordon Golub, a broker with Citi Habitats. ''Previously, they weren't able to get one applicant; now they will have two or three.'' 
 Landlords can see how potential tenants measure up on length of employment, credit score, size and makeup of debt, and income. ''Landlords are getting back to what they were doing four and five years ago and asking for two months' security even if everything is perfect,'' Mr. Golub said. 
 Not only are landlords taking a harder look at a renter's financial picture, but more of them are requesting housing court reports that point to any previous litigation. ''That is one of the newer trends,'' said Yuval Greenblatt, manager of the rental department at Douglas Elliman. 
 Building policies also start to change. When the rental market becomes tighter, ''the dogs have to shrink,'' Mr. Greenblatt said. In a tougher market, 40-pound dogs are no longer welcome. Perks that luxury buildings offered to new tenants are also disappearing. ''One building was offering free breakfast five days a week, and that ended,'' Mr. Golub said. 
 When there are many financially stable apartment hunters, including some with a lot of capital from a recent apartment sale, landlords are less inclined to compromise and accept renters who want to carve out an extra bedroom with a temporary wall.
 Brokers report that apartments at the highest end of the market, such as those renting for more than $8,000 a month, still remain available for longer stretches. But over all, landlords are enjoying a boom they haven't seen in years.
 ''Last August every landlord was staying in the city because they were worried,'' said Mark Shemel, president of National Property Management Group, which manages more than 600 units across Manhattan. ''This year they were all away in the Hamptons.''
