HEADLINE: Bringing Down the House In Fairfield County

BYLINE: By C.J. HUGHES

 BODY:
IT'S a milestone, yes, but not one that Fairfield County residents, preservationists, even some home builders are particularly proud of. 
 Homeowners and developers are ripping down homes at a faster rate than anyone can remember. With more than three months to go in 2004, many of the communities in Fairfield County are about to surpass the number of tear-downs for all of 2003 and some, including Fairfield, Stamford and Westport, already have.
 Indeed, the tear-down blitz has caused such alarm all over the state that more municipalities are beginning to pass laws to slow it, adding to the dozens of towns that already have such laws. Hamden, for example, recently passed a law to delay demolitions, while New Canaan, Ridgefield, and Guilford are debating similar restrictions. 
 ''This is extremely unusual, never happened before that I know of,'' said Marian Castell, Darien's town historian, about the level of tear-downs. ''There is no doubt we are at historic levels.''
 Tear-downs occur all over the state, but in many of the towns around Hartford, in Litchfield County, and from New Haven to New London, they are more of a trickle. Essex, for example, has had one this year; Litchfield none. But Fairfield County is a virtual deconstruction site, fueled by, developers and real estate experts said, increased demand for housing and, especially, larger housing.
 In Darien, 26 demolition permits for single-family homes were issued by late last week, just one shy of the 27 for all of last year. Ridgefield issued 27 permits in its fiscal year ending in June, compared with 24 last fiscal year. In Norwalk, the pace is a bit slower, with 24 permits issued as of late last week, compared with 34 last year. New Canaan issued 37 permits through June, the latest numbers available, compared with 57 last year.
 By the middle of this month, Stamford had already surpassed its 2003 tear-downs, with 28 permits, compared with 24 last year. So has Fairfield, with 41 permits, passing the 38 from last year, and Westport, with 74, up from 71.
 All of those communities were quiet by the standards of Greenwich, which issued 138 demolition permits in its fiscal year ending in June, compared with 82 the previous year.
 While the racket of tear-downs may be annoying to neighbors or a tacky McMansion replacing an old Greek Revival may wrinkle some noses, preservationists are concerned that some significant old homes are being destroyed. A group of Victorian homes in a neighborhood that was once an Irish and African-American working-class enclave in Greenwich is scheduled to be torn down, angering preservationists. Some Madison residents are trying to save a home built in the late 1600's from demolition, and in Ellington, a home built in 1776 was headed for the Dumpster until the developer had second thoughts after pleas from residents.
 ''This is a widespread problem, because the pace of it is faster than the ability to get hold of it,'' said Helen Higgins, the executive director of the Connecticut Trust for Historic Preservation, which urges people to think twice before tearing down houses. ''The character of the community is clearly at risk when you rip apart its fabric.''
 Of course, old doesn't always mean historic. Some people involved in tear-downs said the new homes they planned to build would be much better than what was there.
 ''There isn't anything that remarkable about these homes,'' said Judy Larson, the architect on the Greenwich project, who described herself as a preservationist. ''But sometimes you have to make a call, and in the end, I want to make beautiful buildings.''
 In all cases, housing officials said a shortage of empty lots is driving the trend. And developers are ripping down one house and putting two or more in its place. That's happening in Westport, for example, where what land is left is either on a rocky ledge or in a wetland, said Don Miro, a builder who is also chairman of the town's Historic District Commission.
 ''There just isn't the land available, and there still seems to be huge demand,'' Mr. Miro said. Low interest rates are also having an effect by helping create increased demand for housing.
 ''When interest rates are low like they are now, the best return on people's money is in real estate,'' Mr. Miro said. ''The bottom line is, low rates are also good for spec builders.''
 In many cases, it has become cheaper to buy an old house, rip it down, and put up a new one, than it would be to, say, shore up crumbling foundations and strengthen supporting frames in a drooping two-centuries-old farmhouse.
 Still, the cost of this approach can seem staggeringly high. In Westport, according to housing experts, a lot with a home eyed for tear-down can start at about $700,000. In Greenwich, it's even higher, around $800,000. Builders said it can typically cost $15,000 for demolition and, in Fairfield County, about $250 a square foot, or $600,000 for a 2,400 square-foot home, to build a nicer house.
 Yet another, less tangible, factor is taste.
 People tend to want to live in historic neighborhoods, but not in old buildings, said Ms. Higgins of the Connecticut Trust for Historic Preservation.
 ''Families today feel like they have to have a million different rooms, even though they really just spend time in one main room,'' she said.
 Tastes might be tough to change overnight, but one tool that is proving helpful against the tear-down epidemic are demolition delay laws, usually coordinated through a town's historic district commission.
 Typically, a delay of 90 days can be activated if a house that's scheduled to be torn down is located in a historic district; if it's more than 50 years old (60 in Greenwich); or if it's included on a special town list of noteworthy buildings (like in New Haven).
 During the delay period, any resident can come forward and make their case why the proposed demolition shouldn't take place. The idea is, the owner will hear the arguments, change their minds, and revise their plans.
 ''We're concerned just as all communities in Fairfield County about the ability to be notified once these permits are filed,'' said Gary Singer of the Ridgefield Historical Society, who is helping draft the delay law in that town. ''Once these resources are lost they are irreplaceable.''
 Although these laws can stall demolitions, they can't stop them, and town officials said it is rare when owners reverse course.
 That hasn't stopped a group of neighbors in Greenwich from trying to save three adjacent Victorian homes on Sherwood Place inside a 159-building National Register of Historic Places district.
 Local builders want to demolish the somewhat tatty turn-of-the-century structures to make way for new multifamily homes. In fact, the new buildings, with their planned wraparound porches and wood fish-scale shingles, may even improve on the originals' vinyl siding and aluminum trim.
 Yet neighbors said that the houses should be renovated, not razed.
 ''We recognize you can't save every single house,'' said Bill Schneider, who has galvanized support by handing out pamphlets and writing letters to local, state and national politicians. ''But when you see something coming in that looks like Levittown,'' he said, referring to the Long Island suburb, ''it will only encourage other developers.''
 Appealing to the state, Mr. Schneider has asked the Connecticut Historical Commission to delay demolition on the Sherwood Place homes for an additional 90 days, after the first 90-day delay ends this fall. Susan Chandler, the commission's historical architect, said she is discussing the matter with the builders.
 Meanwhile, the building industry in Connecticut is trying to cope with demolition delay laws while still faced with a seemingly insatiable appetite for larger and more luxurious houses.
 ''The demand for housing in Fairfield County is still very strong,'' said Greg Ugalde, a builder who also serves as president of the 1,100-member Homebuilders Association of Connecticut. ''It has required purchasers of homes to get creative to fulfill the need,'' which sometimes means having to tear homes down.
 Some battles over old homes, however, are igniting debates about how aggressive towns need to pre-empt the problem.
 In Madison, where tear-downs have almost doubled this year from last, going from four to seven, the most recent spat was over a clapboard saltbox on 10 acres known as the David Field House, whose oldest section dates to the late 1600's.
 Because there are no local demolition delay laws on the books, the town's zoning board easily approved Michael Montanaro, the builder, to put four new homes on the property.
 Even though preservationists are hopeful they can find a buyer for the Field House and move it before construction starts, they said they were hindered in their efforts to save it.
 ''I would like to see the town fathers do more to protect houses like this,'' said Jane Kuhl, former president of the Madison Historical Society. ''Our town is in the bull's-eye right now.''
 In Ellington, the Pinney House, a gable-roofed colonial completed in 1776 that is next to dozens of new, attached apartments, may be saved.
 Eric Santini, a developer who originally planned on demolishing the home, is working with the Friends of the Pinney House, a preservation group, to spare it by moving the house across the street.
 Still, many residents were caught unawares by the town's swift approval of the project.
 ''I was shocked that our zoning board approved this development site near this historic structure,'' said Dale Roberson, a lawyer and chairman of Friends of the Pinney House. ''This is the second-oldest house in our town.''
 Clifford Aucter, vice chairman of Ellington's Planning and Zoning Board, said the developer had at first thought the house could not be saved.
 ''The house wasn't even taken into consideration, not out of callousness, it just wasn't taken into consideration,'' he said. ''The developer found it wasn't economically feasible to save it.''
 Some homeowners who changed their minds during the demolition-delay process are outspoken about their conversions.
 Emily Laux bought her 1896 Westport farmhouse on two acres in June 1997 and after some frustrating attempts to renovate the place, decided to start from scratch. Yet a local architect intervened, convincing her the original structures were worth saving.
 Since then, Ms. Laux has become a strong advocate of the preservation approach, frustrated by the ''over-the-top'' McMansions with high fences, wide driveways, and treeless lawns that now line her Cross Highway neighborhood.
 ''I have developed a visual fondness for old properties when I pass by them,'' Ms. Laux said. ''I can only hope that what we did encourages others to do the same.''

HEADLINE: The Utility Company Around the Corner

BYLINE: By GAIL BRACCIDIFERRO

 BODY:
THE general manager of Norwich's utilities department was visiting an industrial customer one day when he learned the business was planning to leave the city.
 The owner said although railroad tracks and a road near his factory were essential to his business, they also were hemming it in and preventing him from expanding.
 ''We asked what we could do to keep him in the city and he talked about moving the road,'' said Richard E. DesRoches, general manager of the Norwich Department of Public Utilities.
 Utilities and community development officials then persuaded the city government to expand sewer and fire protection to the site and relocate a section of road to create five acres of developable land adjacent to the factory. The Otrobando Avenue business currently called US Foodservice, expanded three times since the initial conversation a decade ago, Mr. DesRoches said. In 2003, the company paid the city nearly $12,000 in real estate taxes. 
 ''The city has been collecting more taxes and selling more electricity there all along,'' he said. ''In the regular marketplace it wouldn't have happened because no one goes to that kind of trouble.''
 Personalized attention and community-oriented service is typical for municipally owned utility companies, however, Mr. DesRoches and other municipal utilities officials and their customers said.
 In Norwich, the utility not only works to keep and attract businesses, but also promotes environmental friendliness by undertaking projects such as the operation of a fleet of natural gas vehicles and building a $2.5 million fish lift that has allowed several species of fish to return to the upper reaches of the Shetucket River. 
 In Groton, the utility company expanded into the cable television business after its customers asked it to do so. 
 Now, Glenn M. Wilson, the Groton Utilities Director, said Groton was the first area in the state where customers have a choice of what will provide their cable television service: the privately owned Comcast or the municipally owned Thames Valley Communications.
 Representatives of other municipal utilities in the state said their utilities also participate in a variety of educational programs in local schools, work to keep their rates lower than their privately owned competitors, help lower property taxes by contributing money directly to their municipalities and generally restore power more quickly after outages.
 ''Traditionally, public power is about better service,'' Patrick Hyland, executive director of the Northeast Public Power Association in Milford, Mass., said. ''The crews and maintenance staff are closer to the customers and live in the community. And typically, the rates are lower by between 10 percent and 15 percent.''
 Connecticut Light and Power lists $64.04 as an average monthly bill for a residential customer using 500 kilowatt hours of electricity during a summer month, according to information posted on its Web site. A similar Norwich Utilities customer would pay $58.20 -- about 9 percent lower -- for the same electric use at the same time of year, utilities officials said. Nationally, there are more than 2,000 public power companies and about 43 million Americans, or 14 percent of all customers, get their electricity from publicly owned utilities, according to statistics from the American Public Power Association in Washington, D.C.
 In Connecticut, however, just 4.2 percent of customers get electricity from a municipally owned utility, Madalyn Cafruny, director of communications for the national association, said.
 There are six municipal electric companies in the state: Norwich, Groton, Wallingford, Jewett City and two separate companies that serve different areas of Norwalk. The Norwich and Groton companies are celebrating their centennials this year, while those in Jewett City, Wallingford and South Norwalk are older. Norwalk's Third District Electric Department, now 91 years old, is Connecticut's youngest municipal electric company.
 All electric companies, including municipally owned ones, trace their roots to the 1880's, when Thomas Edison introduced the concept of generating electricity at a central facility and sending it by wires to remote locations. Many private entrepreneurs jumped into the business.
 Maurice Scully, chief operating officer of the Connecticut Municipal Electric Energy Cooperative, said many of the state's original electric companies later merged or were bought by private, for-profit companies such as Connecticut Light & Power. Some municipalities entered the electric business to power streetlights and then expanded to light up homes and businesses. Other municipalities bought up the private companies that set up shop in their towns.
 Today, municipal utilities are not regulated by the state's Department of Public Utility Control. Instead, local utilities commissioners are appointed to oversee operations and make policy decisions for each municipal utility.
 ''The public utilities that survived, the municipalities saw some benefit to keeping them,'' Mr. Scully said. ''In some places, they are now the hallmarks of their communities. They show foresight on the part of their forefathers.''
 The Norwich-based electric cooperative formed in 1976. All of Connecticut's municipal utilities belong to the cooperative, which provides them with more buying power on the wholesale electric market.
 The smallest of Connecticut's municipal electric companies is in Jewett City, a borough of the town of Griswold. The director, Joseph Dudek, who has worked for the company for 44 years, said it provides power to 2,000 customers. 
 On the other end of the size spectrum is Wallingford's electric utility that serves 24,000 customers, including a number of large industrial users, said Richard Hendershot, general manager of the electric division there.
 Groton Utilities also serves industrial customers such as Pfizer's pharmaceutical research and development operation, General Dynamics' Electric Boat submarine shipyard and the United States Navy Submarine base.
 Utility commissioner Julio Leandri said these three entities account for about 60 percent of the Groton company's energy output.
 ''When Pfizer came here, their big concern was how much water we could supply,'' said Mr. Leandri, who worked at the utility for 38 years before retiring in 1985. ''We promised to give them what they needed.'' 
 Groton Utilities supplies both water and electricity to its customers.
 While officials at all municipal utilities said they work to keep their rates lower than those at privately owned utilities, they said local taxpayers also benefit from utility company payments made directly into municipal coffers.
 ''The property taxes would double in the city if we weren't here,'' Mr. Wilson of Groton said.
 In Norwich, Mr. DesRoches said 10 percent of the utilities' billed revenues go directly to the city's general fund. This year, Norwich utilities contributed more than $5 million to the city in this manner.
 Mr. Leandri, who has served as a Groton utilities commissioner since 1987, two years after retiring from his utilities job, said although customers appreciate lower rates and lower taxes, they especially enjoy being able to talk to a real person no matter what time they call to report a problem. 
 ''Municipal utilities have more focused service,'' Mr. Scully said. ''It's more a part of the fabric of the community. Everything the employees and the management do tends to focus on what they can do for the community.''
 Mr. Wilson in Groton puts it this way, ''Our customers are our investors.''
 ''We've been here 100 years and we'll be here another 100,'' Mr. Leandri said. ''Customers know we make no decision without them in mind.''

SECTION: Section 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk; Second Front; A Plan to Transform Manhattan's Frontier Unsettles the Pioneers; Pg. 37

LENGTH: 1645 words

HEADLINE: Many Say Redevelopment Along Hudson Would Displace Their Homes and Businesses

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI

 BODY:
Real estate developers hunting for new development sites call the far West Side of Manhattan the last frontier. The Bloomberg administration calls it a blighted wasteland ready for radical transformation.
 But Benoit Lagarde, Kitty Burke, Richard Silver and others who live or own businesses in the neighborhood call it home. Along with Mercedes-Benz Manhattan and Federal Express, which operate large operations on the far West Side, they have begun to resist the city's sweeping redevelopment plan for the area, fearing that it will dislodge them from their houses and offices.
 In a city where residents battle developers with the same fervent determination that developers try to enlarge the skyline, they say they are not knee-jerk opponents of development. Indeed, they want the sometimes drab streets and battered brick buildings of the old industrial area spruced up. They also favor building more apartments and office towers, and expanding the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. 
 Ms. Burke, who owns the industrial building on 34th Street that houses Federal Express and is designated for demolition, said the city should rezone the area and let the real estate market take its course, rather than specifying development sites and putting her and others out of business.
 After enduring life on the West Side in the bad old days when prostitutes were among the most aggressive entrepreneurs on 11th Avenue, she and others do not want the wrecking ball to destroy their homes or businesses to make way for what they say is an unprecedented level of development: the equivalent of 13 Empire State Buildings and 12,800 apartments envisioned in the city's ambitious master plan.
 It is not hard to see why the seemingly inexorable march of development is edging closer to the West Side, where about 30 percent of the 60-block area west of Eighth Avenue to the Hudson River, from 28th to 42nd Streets, is vacant or underused. The small scale of the neighborhood's industrial past is evident in its factory buildings, warehouses and tenements, which once housed longshoremen who worked the docks nearby. Bounded by 11th and 12th Avenues, between 30th and 33rd Streets, the railyard where the city and the Jets want to build a riverside football stadium is 150 years old. To the north, the area is crisscrossed by entrances to the Lincoln Tunnel and ramps leading to the Port Authority Bus Terminal.
 Like many of the city's other once-grimy neighborhoods, the West Side has already been undergoing something of a renaissance, with new businesses, art galleries and restaurants opening alongside industrial operations. Residents say the city's plan will be inhospitable to the small- and medium-size businesses that have been there for years and those that are just beginning to take root.
 ''I'm very much concerned with where the small-business man can set up his establishment within Manhattan to serve all the needs of Manhattan,'' said Mr. Silver, president of American Pipe and Tank on West 35th Street, near 11th Avenue. ''What will happen to fellows like myself or my son? Where do we go? How do I service my client base if they take this area away?''
 Mr. Silver's company builds and installs the wooden and steel water tanks that adorn the crowns of many high-rises. Under the city's plan, the building he has owned since 1972, along with dozens of others, would be condemned and razed for a new boulevard stretching from 42nd to 34th Streets, between 10th and 11th Avenues.
 The city's draft environmental review, which identifies specific sites for residential or commercial development, estimates that at least 225 businesses and 4,269 employees would be directly displaced, as well as 139 residents in 10 buildings.
 Like Federal Express and Mercedes-Benz Manhattan, Mr. Silver says he must be near his customers and would be unable to find an alternative location in Midtown.
 In some cases, property would be condemned by the city. Property owners seeking compensation would then have to debate the value in court.
 The Bloomberg administration says the relatively low-scale far West Side is the only place in Manhattan where the city can expand to meet the need for first-class office space over the next 30 years. Deputy Mayor Daniel L. Doctoroff, who has led the city's West Side effort, says that it is crucial to the city's future that it be able to expand and that the West Side is the logical place to do it. The city estimates that the development would generate 110,930 jobs by 2025 and about $2 billion in annual tax revenues.
 The rezoning plan, which would allow for large-scale development, is currently wending its way through the city's approval process, with a public hearing on Thursday at the Department of City Planning.
 Some property owners in the area agree with the city's plan, saying it will speed the neighborhood's rebirth and be a boon to the rest of the city.
 ''This isn't about me; it's about greater New York,'' said Richard Zakka, who owns several buildings on West 36th Street that would face demolition and favors the city's plan, known as Hudson Yards. ''The Hudson Yards plan is brilliant.''
 Frank Ford, who runs O'Farrell's, a tavern one block from the Javits Convention Center, at 10th Avenue and West 33rd Street, has embraced the plan. His customers are split between conventioneers and locals, but the tavern is closed most weekends for lack of business.
 He said an expanded convention center, a proposed 75,000-seat stadium for the New York Jets over the nearby railyard, hotels and other development in the area would mean more jobs and more customers. ''It'll be good for every small business and large hotel on the West Side,'' he said.
 Mr. Ford dismissed criticisms of the city's plan and the $1.4 billion stadium, which is widely opposed in the neighborhood. ''There are some people who still want the hookers over here,'' he said, in a reference to the 1970's and 80's. ''People resist change.''
 But others want a slower pace. Members of Community Board 4, whose district embraces the Hudson Yards site, say the area must be developed, but not as aggressively as the city proposes. Like some economists, the board has suggested that the city is being overly optimistic in projecting the need for expensive office buildings on the far West Side, where more than 20,000 people make their home. For one thing, more than 10 million square feet of new office space is planned for Lower Manhattan in the coming years. 
 ''We're fully in favor of developing the area,'' said the community board chairman, Walter Mankoff. ''We support a bigger Javits and think this should be a major residential area with a significant commercial component. It's a question of whether you want 30-story buildings or 80-story buildings.''
 Camilla Pettle, who lives in a four-story walk-up across the street from Mr. Silver's business and works at the Cupcake Cafe on Ninth Avenue, said she worried that the city's plan for wholesale development would destroy the vibrant mix of retail, residential and industrial life taking root here. 
 ''They keep saying there's nothing here,'' Ms. Pettle said. ''But this neighborhood has a real personality. There's enough space here for everyone to get some of what they want. But they're tearing a hole in the middle of a neighborhood that's already been destroyed by the tunnels and stuff like that.''
 There are dozens of small and medium-size businesses scattered through the district and an increasing number of residents. New residential development has made the leap across Eighth Avenue, especially in west Chelsea and along 42nd Street, spurred in part by the rejuvenation of Times Square.
 In the migratory patterns of New York real estate, art galleries forced out by rising rents in SoHo have moved to west Chelsea at the southern end of Hudson Yards, and nightclubs like the Copacabana have opened on 11th Avenue.
 Benoit Lagarde, a founder of Splashlight Studios at 529 West 35th Street, said he loved the eclectic mix of his street and the way his photographic studios feed off the printer next door and the lighting and motion picture equipment business across the street. In 2001, Mr. Lagarde and a partner invested $8.5 million in an old industrial building, transforming it into busy fashion studios and creating a small restaurant on the ground floor. But under the city's plan, the building would be demolished.
 ''We need to be on the West Side, where all the fashion directors, photographers and modeling agencies are,'' Mr. Lagarde said. ''This could destroy us. It would stop my business as it is today.''
 Next door, Wayne Sapper, president of King Displays, a company that prints most of the signs, displays and marquees for the theater district, said the building he is in would also be razed. He said he moved to West 35th Street in 1987 to be close to his customers. ''The West Side is doing fine on its own,'' he said. ''We need an expansion of the Javits, but I don't think we have to destroy a neighborhood to do it.''
 Federal Express, which has a large distribution center at 34th Street and 11th Avenue, has told the city that it would probably have to move to New Jersey because it could not find an alternative location in Midtown that would accommodate the 129 vans that now operate there. That would mean, Federal Express told Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, that it would have to send more trucks through the Lincoln Tunnel, adding to traffic congestion and pollution. 
 Ms. Burke, the company's landlord, opposes the condemnation and demolition of the building her grandfather built, when he created the Bulwark Corporation, the family's heirloom against poverty and dissolution.
 ''The West Side needs and deserves to be developed to a certain degree,'' Ms. Burke said. ''It's the last frontier. But they shouldn't destroy things that are good for development and the city.''

HEADLINE: In Crete, Mobility With a Guide and a Glide

BYLINE: By MARILYNNE RUDICK. 
MARILYNNE RUDICK is a writer in Chevy Chase, Md.

 BODY:
AS our plane landed in Iraklion, I considered whether sea kayaking in Crete was going to be a peak experience or a long way to go for a gyro sandwich. For years I'd listened enviously to my friends' tales of adventure travel. I have multiple sclerosis, so trekking in Tibet was out. But kayaking -- which requires upper body strength, not leg power -- seemed like a good bet. 
 After seeing an ad in Outside magazine for inn-to-inn kayaking in Crete, I called the outfitter, the Northwest Passage, and explained what I could do (kayak) and couldn't do (walk more than a short distance). Could they accommodate me on their September trip? ''Absolutely,'' Adam Walsh assured me. He described an eight-day kayaking adventure that combined physical challenge, great natural beauty and the comfort of staying in a family-owned inn -- a firm mattress and a hot shower -- after a hard day of paddling. 
 Despite Adam's assurances, I worried about my abilities and disabilities. Along with my quick-dry wardrobe and headlamps for exploring sea caves, I packed a hefty supply of books as a hedge. 
 Our kayaking adventure began in Matala, on Crete's south coast. In addition to my husband, Bob, and me, there were seven other paddlers ranging in age from 23 to 58. We were the only couple; the others were assorted singles from New York, Chicago, Santa Fe, San Diego and British Columbia. Our group of six women and three men was a mixture of experienced kayakers and novices. 
 Our two guides were Rick Sweitzer and Mike Agostinelli. We learned that Rick, the Northwest Passage's founder, has led expeditions all over the world, including the North and South Poles. Mike is a kayak instructor, firefighter and paramedic, whose remarkable talents unfolded throughout the week. 
 The morning after our arrival in Matala, outfitted with paddles, life jackets and spray skirts, which keep the sea out of the cockpit, we gathered at the beach for our initiation. Strong winds rattled the palm trees, and whitecaps whipped up the bay as Mike initiated us in paddling basics. Nevertheless, we gamely launched our kayaks. 
 Bob and I shared a double kayak, which promised stability and comfort. In the front, I was to set the pace; in the back, Bob provided power and steered, using foot pedals to control the rudder. It seemed as though we'd been out all day when we took a break -- two hours! My arms and shoulders ached, and I wondered about the afternoon, let alone the entire week.
 That night, an optional easy sunset hike was planned. I asked Rick whether he thought I could do the hike on my lightweight electric scooter. He said no, but he proposed another way. ''How do you feel about being carried?'' My initial reaction: ''I'll skip the hike and meet up for dinner.'' But Janie, another kayaker, gave me a sharp jab. ''Are you crazy? Rick and Mike are hunks. Don't turn this down!'' 
 I envisioned Mike and Rick rigging up a seat in which I'd be carried like a Mediterranean potentate on a litter. But my litter carrier turned out to be just Mike, and my litter was Mike's back. Mike hoisted me -- 120 pounds -- and carried me piggy-back as he rock-scrambled up the mountain. 
 From then on, Mike had Zeus-like status. And that was before Mike, also a massage therapist, set up his table on the roof of the hotel, and accompanied by a soft breeze and starlit sky, massaged away my stiff neck and shoulders. Mike's postdinner massage (included in the trip) became a nightcap for three or four of that day's neediest. 
 When Adam assured me that the Northwest Passage could accommodate me, I had imagined the normal arrangements: ground-floor rooms, van transportation if needed, help getting in and out of kayaks. I had not anticipated making the mountain accessible. 
 But over the course of the week as I watched Rick and Mike gracefully attend to everyone's different needs, I realized that figuring out how to make this trip accessible for me was just another expedition challenge -- like getting a team of dog sledders to the North Pole.
 The plan was to travel to the westernmost point of our trip, Agia Roumeli. Then we would spend the rest of the week paddling our way along the southern coast back to Matala, a distance of about 75 miles. We'd paddle five to seven hours a day, covering between 8 and 24 miles daily.
 We were kayaking in that part of the Mediterranean known as the Libyan Sea. In Crete, we were about halfway between Athens and Libya. 
 When we launched our kayaks from the beach at Agia Roumeli, the winds had died down and the water was as advertised -- smooth as sea glass. Our days took on a comfortable rhythm: an after-breakfast launch, a midmorning cappuccino stop at a beach taverna, a few more hours of paddling to our lunch taverna, and then several hours of paddling to that night's destination. Most days, our pace was leisurely, leaving plenty of time, in Rick's words, ''to follow our inner bliss.'' 
 That meant meandering along the coast, paddling in water that reflected the muted grays of the hills and the sky's color wheel of blues. The weather was perfect, both the air and the water in the high 70's, without a hint of humidity and only an occasional cloud. 
 Each day was a variation on the theme. Our stops included Agios Pavlos, where an 11th-century stone chapel honors St. Paul, reputedly shipwrecked on the shores of Crete; Sweetwater Beach, where icy springs bubble out of the sand; and Palm Beach, where a fresh-water estuary blends into the sea. Some days we explored sea caves, carved out of the craggy limestone cliffs that line the coast. 
 While all our overnights were in charming seaside towns, Loutro, where we spent two nights, was the stand-out, its brilliant white buildings, all with blue trim, set against a backdrop of fawn and peach hills.
 At a family-owned restaurant in Loutro, we dined as a group, as we did all but one night.Typically we'd shared a groaning board of appetizers: stuffed grape leaves, eggplant salads, saganaki (fried cheese) and always tzatziki (yogurt, cucumber and garlic dip) and Greek salads.
 Our main courses were traditional: lamb, fish, moussaka. Dinner ended with ouzo, or more commonly raki, the Greek version of white lightning. 
 The Crete trip was rated a 1 by the Northwest Passage -- easy, no experience needed. But Gordon, an experienced kayaker from British Columbia, thought it could best be described as covering a range from novice to expert. A van, driven by George Stavroulakis, a retired Cretan sea captain, tailed us, meeting us at our midmorning break, then again at lunch. That meant you could kayak for as long or as short a distance as you liked. 
 One day Janie and I shaved five miles off a 24-mile paddle, opting for a leisurely breakfast, a ferry and a van ride with George, meeting up with the kayakers mid-morning. Van rides had their own rewards: a chance to switch back through mountains, olive groves, vineyards and small villages.
 MOST days, Rick also proposed a hiking alternative for those who did not want to kayak for the entire day. You could, for example, hike in the morning then join the kayakers for the afternoon portion. Obviously, I kayaked rather than hiked. 
 There was only one day when there was just a hike, an 11-mile downhill through the Samarian Gorge. On that day, I ferried with George to the day's destination, Agia Roumeli, at the foot of the gorge, and spent the afternoon on the beach. Another way to change the pace was to trade off between stable double kayaks and the expedition single kayaks. 
 In reading the pretrip briefing material, I felt sure I wouldn't do the final leg on the last day, an eight-mile open-water paddle from Agia Galini back to Matala, described as ''a challenge for the hardiest of paddlers.'' Other than this stretch, we had skimmed the coast, in easy reach of land. 
 But here I was on Day 8 in the front of a double kayak, with Bob in the back, feeling confident about my ability and eager for one last paddle. Rick scheduled an early launch to take advantage of the calm seas. But by the time we were beyond the sheltered harbor, wind and sea had whipped up.
 Rick paddled over to check our comfort level and offer us a chance to turn back. But we'd honed our skills during the week and we felt up to the challenge. For the first hour, Bob and I fought the sea and heavy winds that pummeled our port and pushed us off course.
 But then the wind shifted, and we were on a comfortable run. Our kayak became a surfboard, carried along by the motion of the waves. We relaxed and enjoyed the ride, the crossing and the week ending much too soon. 
 For my final meal in Matala, I had a world-class gyro and tallied my accomplishments. I had kayaked about 90 miles. I was aided by a convivial, supportive group -- and above all, Rick and Mike, who were willing to move mountains to make my trip a success.

If you go

The Trip
 The Northwest Passage, (800) 732-7328, www.nwpassage.com, in Wilmette, Ill., bills itself as the only company offering inn-to-inn kayaking trips in Crete. This fall, there is an eight-day trip starting next Sunday, $2,295 a person in doubleoccupancy, and one starting Oct. 4, which includes yoga with kayaking and hiking, $2,495. The prices include lodging, kayaking equipment, most meals and van support.
 A self-supported trip (no van), starting Oct. 12, is $1,995. 
 Departures in 2005 are mainly in May, June, September and October.

Getting There
 Aegean Air and Olympic Air offer frequent hourlong flights from Athens to Iraklion, Crete. 
 Minoan Lines operate daytime and overnight ferries (six to eight hours) between Athens (Piraeus) and Iraklion. A variety of accommodations is available on the overnight ferries. 
 Ferry rates range from $36 (economy) to $100 (luxury) one-way; prices at $1.25 to the euro. For ferry schedules and rates: www.greekislands.gr/minoan.

HEADLINE: Housing Costs Make Ohio Look Appealing

 BODY:

To the Editor:
 The article, ''Don't Tell Anyone, but There's This Rich Joke Going Around . . . ,'' Sept. 5, about the high cost of living in New Jersey inspires comment. Apparently the median family income in New Jersey is now the highest in the nation at $70,263.00. I'm single, earn more than that, and I still can't afford to buy a home in Hoboken, where I live. 
 But if I could afford a home here, I don't think I could psychologically bear to pay the ridiculously high taxes. Unfortunately, I can afford a home in New Jersey towns or sections of towns where I don't feel safe, or which are remote from the community I've built. I can't be the only person with semi-deep pockets facing this problem. Is there a politician or developer listening? So, while I'm not eager to move out of state, Ohio, with it's median income of $51,522, looks very attractive. There I'll truly be rich, happily relaxing in the shade of my buckeye trees, and content in the knowledge that if global warming continues along its simmering path, I'll be the proud owner of waterfront property just in time for retirement.

Claudia Kreiss
Hoboken

SECTION: Section 12; Column 1; Automobiles; BEHIND THE WHEEL/2004 Suzuki Verona and Forenza; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1671 words

HEADLINE: Not From Around Here, Are You?

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS

DATELINE: DETROIT 

 BODY:
IN today's global auto industry, Chinese workers bolt bumpers onto Jeeps while good ol' boys drive Nissan trucks off the assembly line in Mississippi (and polish Mercedes's three-pointed star in Alabama). 
 But few cars are quite as cosmopolitan as Suzuki's latest sedans, the compact Forenza and midsize Verona.
 Not only were their names inspired by Italian geography, they were styled by Italian designers. They are built in South Korea and sold by an American subsidiary of a Japanese company. Their path to the marketplace began with a complicated deal in which an American conglomerate, General Motors, bought major assets of a bankrupt Korean automaker, Daewoo. G.M. also owns 20 percent of Suzuki, which helps to explain how the Japanese automaker got a piece of the reconstituted Daewoo pie. 
 G.M. now sells various Daewoo models worldwide, including some that wear Chevrolet and Buick nametags. For instance, the Chevrolet Aveo subcompact is known overseas as the Daewoo Kalos.
 But rebadged Daewoos are only a drop in G.M.'s big American bucket, whereas they are a crucial part of the American Suzuki Motor Corporation's strategy to triple its sales here by 2007, to 200,000 a year. In addition to the Verona and Forenza, Suzuki will start to sell the Reno, a car-based utility wagon built by G.M. Daewoo, this fall.
 Suzuki's strategy with the Verona and Forenza is similar to that of the South Korean automakers Kia and Hyundai: offer well-equipped models at lower prices and with longer warranties than the Japanese competition. All Suzukis come with a basic warranty of 3 years or 36,000 miles and a powertrain warranty of 7 years or 100,000 miles; unlike most warranties, these are transferable when the cars are sold. Buyers also receive free roadside assistance for 3 years or 36,000 miles.
 The similarities of the newest Suzuki twosome to other Korean models don't end there. After weeklong test drives of both the Forenza and Verona, I concluded that the Suzukis indeed offer a lot of content at a somewhat lower price, with a warranty that should provide some peace of mind. 
 But the cars lack the refinement and engineering sophistication that consumers have come to expect from the Japanese -- and even from some recent American models like the Chevrolet Malibu and Ford Focus.

Forenza: Pleasing at First Glance
 The smaller of the new Suzukis, the Forenza, was designed by Pininfarina, the studio responsible for some of the most beautiful Ferraris, Maseratis and Alfa Romeos that ever graced the roads of the world. While the Forenza is contemporary and handsome, it will never make the short list of lovely Italian-design automobiles.
 The compact Forenza sedan -- a station wagon version goes on sale next year -- is based on the Daewoo Lucetti. That car replaced the Nubira, which fell in the middle of a Daewoo threesome sold in the United States from 1999 to 2002.
 (When G.M. bought Daewoo's Korean assets, it declined to pick up the American subsidiary, Daewoo Motor America, leaving dealers and existing customers in the lurch. In August, a federal judge in Orlando, Fla., dismissed a suit filed by the Daewoo subsidiary and its dealers against G.M., saying they had no exclusive rights to vehicles manufactured by the new G.M. Daewoo company. A spokesman for Daewoo Motor America said it planned an appeal.)
 The Forenza takes aim at some well-established small cars like the Toyota Corolla, Honda Civic and Nissan Sentra, and at a glance it seems quite competitive.
 The picture darkens a bit when you look at the powertrain. The 2-liter 4-cylinder engine is a modern design (with dual overhead camshafts and four valves per cylinder), but it is rated at just 126 horsepower and 131 pounds-feet of torque. Though many of the Forenza's competitors have smaller engines, they manage to squeeze out as much power, or more; the Focus gets 10 more horsepower out of the same size engine.
 Larger engines that put out less horsepower than smaller ones are a common theme in Korean cars. The front-drive Forenza not only feels underpowered, its government fuel economy ratings are the lowest in the class; 24 miles per gallon in the city and 31 m.p.g. on the highway (with a five-speed manual transmission). Mileage of comparable compact sedans falls broadly in a range of 26 to 40 m.p.g.
 The other available transmission, a four-speed automatic, takes a further toll in both performance and mileage.
 While a Forenza owner will be making more stops at gas stations than those who drive Civics, he or she will ride in reasonable comfort. The cabin is attractively appointed with high-quality materials, comfortable seats and extremely good fit-and-finish. At 12.4 cubic feet, the trunk space is on par with that of other compact cars, and the rear seats fold nearly flat, adding to the potential cargo capacity.
 Acceleration is adequate around town. The ride is smooth, the handling is decent and the stopping is confident, thanks to four-wheel disc brakes. Still, the driving dynamics are not nearly as sporty as some of the offerings from Japanese and American car companies. In particular, the new Mazda 3 and Ford Focus have crisper Euro-style handling and a firmer ride. 
 Indeed, the driving dynamics of many Korean-built automobiles remind me of the soft, floaty cars that American companies used to make. Perhaps Korean engineers think Americans prefer a cushy ride and softer handling. In any case, I suspect that many prospective Forenza buyers care more about reliably getting from Point A to Point B than doing it in a spirited manner.
 The Forenza comes fairly well equipped with one glaring exception: it does not offer side air bags or side curtain bags. In government crash tests, the Forenza scored four out of five possible stars for front passengers but only three stars for side impacts.
 Antilock brakes are a $500 option.
 The Forenza comes as the base S, the midlevel LX and the top-line EX, which can be dressed up further with leather seats and a sunroof. Even the S comes with air-conditioning and power features (windows, door locks and mirrors) that are optional on some rivals. In this class, only Suzuki has standard heated outside mirrors. It also has an audio system with both CD and cassette players, with eight speakers and controls on the steering wheel. The LX and EX add more features, including cruise control. 
 The Forenza starts at $13,994 including destination charge and tops out around $18,000. My test car, a ''desert green'' LX with manual transmission, was well equipped without benefit of options for a price of $14,395. So for less than $15,000 you get a complete car you can probably live with, plus a long warranty and free roadside assistance.
 Automotive Lease Guide, a Santa Barbara, Calif., company that predicts how much specific cars will depreciate, gives the Forenza just one star out of a possible five. That is on par with the Hyundai Accent, but below the Nissan Sentra (four stars), Toyota Corolla (three stars) and Mazda 3 or Ford Focus (two stars each).

Verona: Low Price, Less Power
 The midsize Verona is pitted directly against the Toyota Camry, Honda Accord and Nissan Altima. It, too, was styled in Italy -- in this case, by another famous design firm, ItalDesign. Like the Forenza, it is pleasing to look at, but hardly a knockout.
 The Verona's interior space essentially matches the Camry's, which is to say it is more than adequate for most people in the market for a midsize sedan. The controls are good and the general environment is quite comfortable -- relatively upscale, even. My chief complaint was that the on-off switch for the radio was poorly positioned on the steering wheel; my finger constantly hit it, turning off the radio, while I was driving.
 The front-drive Verona has an in-line 6-cylinder engine, unusual in a class where V-6's dominate. The 2.5-liter power plant is a new design developed with help from Porsche, with dual camshafts and 24 valves. While in-line 6's are typically smoother and quieter than V-6's -- they continue to be a chief attraction of midrange BMW's -- the Verona's was noisier and rougher-running than I had anticipated.
 The transmission is a four-speed automatic; unlike many of its competitors, the Verona doesn't offer a five-speed manual or a five-speed automatic. The Verona's power falls far short of other six-cylinder engines in this class; its 155 horsepower and 177 pounds-feet of peak torque are closer to the ratings of competitive cars with four cylinders. In contrast, the Accord's 3-liter V-6 makes 240 horsepower and the Camry's like-size engine generates 210; the Altima's 3.5-liter V-6 tops the group with 250 horses.
 The Verona's gas mileage, like the Forenza's, falls at the lower end of its class: 20 miles per gallon in town and 28 on the highway.
 The Verona's ride and handling are decent, however, even though the car's suspension is tuned more for comfort than for sport.
 Like the Forenza, the Verona comes in three versions: base S, midlevel LX and top-of-the-line EX. Base prices, including delivery charges, range from $17,994 to $21,494. A top-of-the line EX with the only available option -- the $500 traction control -- tops out at $21,494. A midtrim Camry SE V-6 starts at $25,000 before options, and the top-drawer Camry XLE is more than $26,000. The Accord EX approaches $30,000.
 All Veronas have fog lights, four-wheel disc brakes and heated outside mirrors, not to mention standard power windows and door locks, cruise control, a leather-wrapped steering wheel and shifter, keyless entry and a stereo with CD, cassette player and six speakers. The uplevel versions add antilock brakes (they are $500 extra on the base model) and automatic climate control. 
 But like its smaller sibling and unlike its rivals, the Verona does not have side air bags or inflatable curtains that cover the windows in a side crash. The government has not yet crash-tested the Verona.

INSIDE TRACK: Two attractive and attractively priced cars that are still a bit rough around the edges.

HEADLINE: The Rite of Summer

BYLINE: By Dave Itzkoff. 
Dave Itzkoff is an editor at Spin and the author of ''Lads: A Memoir of Manhood,'' published this month.

 BODY:

THIS IS BURNING MAN
The Rise of a New
American Underground.
By Brian Doherty.
Illustrated. 304 pp.
Little, Brown & Company. $24.95.
 Among the many bizarre summer rituals that compel otherwise sensible Americans to travel thousands of miles and behave like lunatics -- excluding those with the words ''national'' and ''convention'' in their names -- none is as perplexing as the annual observation of Burning Man. The very nature of the weeklong event, which begins in late August in the desert outside Reno, almost defies articulation: is it an outsider art festival or a spontaneous civics experiment? A flash point for a neotribalistic revival? Or just a great place to go get high on Labor Day weekend? 
 Despite the declarative promise of its title, Brian Doherty's book, ''This Is Burning Man,'' barely scratches beneath the surface of those enigmatic alkali flats. This is a shame, because Doherty, a senior editor at Reason magazine and a veteran of ''the Burn'' since 1995, would appear to possess ideal qualifications to explicate the 18-year-old rite for an uninitiated audience. But from the book's opening pages, he seems more concerned with preserving Burning Man's mythology, playing down the festival's obvious roots in centuries-old predecessors like the (possibly apocryphal) rite of Wicker Man, while overstating its philosophical connections to the counterculture movements of 1960's-era figures like Ken Kesey. When Doherty asserts that Kesey's experiments ''struck devastating blows that made chinks in consensual reality'' and that Burning Man ''is now bulldozing boldly and heedlessly through those chinks,'' you may wonder if the author has left behind more than just his objectivity in the Black Rock Playa. 
 The first half of the book is a folksy retelling of Burning Man's mostly organic evolution from an informal gathering of friends on a San Francisco beach to a temporary city with a population of over 30,000, one that now charges an admission fee of up to $250 per person. It's an account that depends heavily on the fuzzy recollections of Burning Man's earliest attendees, particularly its founder, Larry Harvey, a charismatic Bay Area iconoclast who often speaks in proverbs. (Sample aphorism: ''It's not enough to be Jesus. You have to have some disciples.'')
 From there, ''This Is Burning Man'' starts to sketch out some of the festival's longstanding customs -- its barter-only economy, its tradition of dangerous and highly flammable art installations -- but gets continually bogged down in hagiographies of its zanier participants and their eccentric projects, in endlessly cataloging who built what out of what while under the influence of what. Both the author and his subjects frequently employ words like ''faith'' and ''glory'' and ''magic''; they speak of feelings of purposelessness and isolation that weren't resolved until they found Burning Man. No one seems to recognize that this same slanted phraseology could just as easily be wielded by advocates of the Shriners, the Church of Scientology or the Atkins diet -- that there is nothing inherently cool, or even unique, about institutions that derive their power from insularity and take pride in their inability to be understood by nonbelievers. 
 Amid his talk of ''consensual reality,'' ''emotional reality'' and ''raw reality,'' there is a palpable disdain in Doherty's writing for people who are content to exist in boring old real reality, who ''refuse to open their hearts'' to Burning Man ''because of a protective shell of contempt.'' He never sees it as his responsibility to make the festival comprehensible to these same people. That's fine if he wants to write a recruitment guide or a travelogue, but it's not necessarily a commendable impulse in composing a work of journalistic nonfiction.
 When Doherty sheepishly describes Burning Man as ''an event whose impact depends very much on direct experience,'' it's just another way of saying, You had to be there.

SECTION: Section 7; Column 1; Book Review Desk; Pg. 9

LENGTH: 1524 words

HEADLINE: Neither Coke Nor Pepsi

BYLINE: By Michael Oreskes. 
Michael Oreskes is an assistant managing editor of The Times.

 BODY:

THE GOOD FIGHT
Declare Your Independence
and Close the Democracy Gap.
By Ralph Nader.
294 pp. Regan Books. $25.95.

IN PURSUIT OF JUSTICE
Collected Writings, 2000-2003.
By Ralph Nader.
519 pp. Seven Stories Press.
Paper, $19.95.
 FOR much of his career, stretching back better than four decades now, journalists have found it hard to call Ralph Nader what he was. They labeled him a consumer advocate. The phrase was less threatening, but also less complete, than the reality. For as the power of corporations expanded across the years, Ralph Nader's place as their most relentless critic grew too. Now, in ''The Good Fight,'' and in a collection of previously published columns, ''In Pursuit of Justice,'' Nader, a Harvard-trained lawyer, offers his case that virtually all of America's woes can be traced to the rise and growing power of what he calls multinational corporate predators. 
 It would seem a timely argument. The rise of the global corporation is surely a defining aspect of modern history, and the view that corporations are just highly efficient mechanisms for maximizing economic good has taken a real drubbing in the Enron era. ''Autocratic global corporations are deep into strategic planning,'' Nader roars. ''They openly and confidently strive to control our jobs; our environment; our political and educational institutions; our food, drugs and other consumptions; our savings; our childhoods; our culture; even our genetic futures. Toward these ends, they incessantly move to control our elections and our governmental institutions.''
 There is of course a polemic power in the overdrawn. What Philip K. Dick is to fiction Ralph Nader is to politics. The future, a la Nader, is a darkening place if we fail to act before the ''artificial entities called corporations'' complete their takeover. ''Is it not time for real people to plan for their own futures together?'' Nader asks. (When he finishes his tour as governor of California, perhaps Arnold Schwarzenegger can play Ralph Nader in the movie.) Nader's voice is full of anger and frustration. He rages as much as reasons. This will no doubt please those who already follow him. But for the doubters, and there are more now than before his 2000 presidential campaign helped toss the election into the Supreme Court, his unmeasured tone suits the role of campaigner better than that of conscience. 
 In fairness, the language above, from Nader's introduction to ''The Good Fight,'' is followed by 286 pages in which he details his specific case on each point. On some he is fascinating. He offers a trenchant treatment of the argument that trial lawyers, far from being money-grubbing ambulance chasers, perform a public service by forcing corporations to consider the potential financial cost (via liability actions) of pollution, unsafe products and mistreatment of workers.
 Nader's books make something of a matched set with ''The Corporation: The Pathological Pursuit of Profit and Power,'' by Joel Bakan, a Canadian law professor. Where Bakan tries to offer an intellectual overview of what he describes as the amoral nature of the modern corporation, Nader assembles his evidence from the rubble of his 40 years of combat -- and also by lifting from Bakan. 
 Bakan argues that corporations behave ''pathologically'' because of their inherent logic and legal obligation to pursue profit without regard to external costs borne by others. Nader says he made a similar argument to a conference of psychologists years ago. Both then seek to show how the restraints that hold this drive in check -- unions, communities, even national governments -- have been overridden by the scale of the modern corporation. Both cite Milton Friedman and others in defense of the focus on profit. Nader also quotes Peter F. Drucker, the preeminent student of American management: ''If you find an executive who wants to take on social responsibility, fire him. Fast.'' The quotation is eye-catching, because it directly contradicts Drucker's earlier views. ''In modern society there is no other leadership group but managers,'' Drucker wrote in the 1970's. ''If the managers of our major institutions, and especially of business, do not take responsibility for the common good, no one else can or will.'' 
 Now, Nader's book doesn't have footnotes. But Bakan's (which is in Nader's bibliography) does, and in Bakan's footnotes the current comment is attributed to an interview.
 There is something quite unsettling about Drucker's 70's vision of the noblesse oblige of the corporate executive (Drucker says, by the way, that he hasn't changed his views but that Bakan, and then Nader, took his current comment out of context). Surely, Nader and Bakan could have made a more sophisticated hay with that idea. Evidently turning an icon into a straw man was so appealing that neither of them was willing or able to grapple with Drucker's full thinking on a topic both of them say is profoundly important. If society's fate hangs in the balance, as Nader argues, once over lightly isn't good enough.
 Nader has written a number of previous books. Exactly how many is hard to pin down. In ''Crashing the Party,'' his description of his 2000 presidential campaign, in which he played the iceberg to Al Gore's Titanic, he lists 16 previous books, including many written with colleagues from the various citizens groups he has spawned. In the front of ''The Good Fight,'' he lists only four, including ''Crashing the Party'' and a book on corporate lawyers with Wesley J. Smith. Why he dropped those other books is a puzzle, but a minor one. Because whatever the number only one work will be long remembered, his first. ''Unsafe at Any Speed'' is his detailed portrait of how the auto industry willfully resisted safety innovations and thus contributed to thousands of highway deaths a year. That book deserves a place in the canon of American muckraking alongside the works of Lincoln Steffens and Ida Tarbell.
 His battle with the automakers established Ralph Nader. In his history of the Ford Motor Company, Douglas Brinkley says Nader ''stalked General Motors like a big game-hunter desperate for a kill.'' That intensity changed the balance of power between the makers and the buyers of automobiles. Brinkley relates a visit by Henry Ford II and Lee Iacocca to the Oval Office of Richard Nixon (who of course taped the session). ''They're a group of people that aren't really one damn bit interested in safety or clean air,'' the ever-calculating Nixon told the auto executives. ''What they're interested in is destroying the system. They're enemies of the system.''
 Whether that was true of Nader then he will have to tell us in a more autobiographical book. But it is certainly true of him now. Or perhaps he would prefer to say that he wishes to destroy the power of megacorporations so as to retrieve the American system of representative democracy. ''The Good Fight'' includes Nader's disclaimer that ''this book is not about my current political campaign.'' But if not, then what is his current political campaign about? 
 Democrats like to blame Nader for costing them the White House in 2000. He was in fact only one of a variety of reasons. But he was one, and he offers no apology. ''More and more the major parties become Coke and Pepsi, frantically highlighting their dwindling differences and masking their growing similarities,'' he writes. And his collection of columns includes several fierce attacks on Al Gore, including an almost cruel one in which he holds Gore up as a disappointment compared with his father.
 Like most of Nader's life, ''The Good Fight'' is fundamentally a call to action. ''The subjugation of civic values to commercial values represents one of the worst crises of our times,'' he writes, and is happening because corporations have filled a political vacuum left by apathetic citizens. The disengagement of many Americans from politics is surely one of the nation's great problems. Robin Toner, Richard L. Berke and I wrote that 13 years ago for The New York Times, and the problem has only deepened since. But Nader goes a step further and, in my view, too far. Civic disengagement has several interwoven causes, including the satisfaction of some Americans with their share of the nation's enormous wealth. It can equally well be argued that the political power of corporations is an effect of declining civic participation, not its cause. But subtlety is not Nader's strong suit. The intensity that forced safety measures in cars and saved thousands of lives four decades ago now makes it harder for the uncertain -- including those who might think there is a difference between John Kerry and George W. Bush -- to listen to his calls for action. 
 ''Democracy does take a no-excuses attitude, a positive refusal to become discouraged,'' Nader writes. ''The reverse option is to continue losing more and more control over most everything that matters to us.'' So learn the issues, participate, vote, he urges. Oh, forgive me, I forgot. This book is not about his current campaign. Or maybe some corporate lawyer from his publishing house told him he had to say that.

SECTION: Section 4; Column 2; Editorial Desk; What Should Kerry Do?; Pg. 11

LENGTH: 534 words

HEADLINE: Bringing the Battle to the President

BYLINE: By Paul Glastris. 
Paul Glastris, a former speechwriter for President Bill Clinton, is editor in chief of The Washington Monthly.

DATELINE: Washington 

 BODY:
Senator John Kerry will lose the election unless he turns the issue of national security to his advantage. He began to do so, for the first time in weeks, with his speech on Thursday in Las Vegas, where he took President Bush to task for not being honest about the war in Iraq. In an earlier speech on the economy, he also tore into Mr. Bush's penchant for shifting blame to others. 
 This general strategy, of tracing the president's policy failings to his character flaws, is the right one. But to make it work, Mr. Kerry is going to have to show some character himself.
 First, he must offer a forthright defense of his vote in 2002 to authorize the use of force in Iraq. But that defense will never be accepted unless he also accepts some responsibility for the consequences of his vote.
 Indeed, he could create a ''Richard Clarke moment'' for himself by saying something like the following: ''I voted to give my president the authority he needed to unite the world in confronting Iraq. He abused that authority. But I trusted him, and I now share responsibility for the failing situation in Iraq. As president, I will take responsibility for fixing it -- and that, Mr. President, makes one of us.''
 Second, Mr. Kerry must offer a better plan for Iraq than Mr. Bush's. Mr. Kerry has recently set a goal of pulling American troops out of Iraq in four years. That's the right policy. But as presented, it sounds more like a plan for managing failure than for achieving success.
 A better formulation would be along these lines: ''History shows that no nation can win its freedom unless its people are willing to fight for it. The president is undermining the motivation of the Iraqi people by making an open-ended promise that America will fight their battles for them. We made that mistake in Vietnam; we must not make it now. America will equip and train the people of Iraq, but in the end, they are responsible for choosing their own destiny.''
 Third, Mr. Kerry must offer a better plan for fighting Al Qaeda. So far, he has put forth the worthy but rather airy promise that he will work more energetically with America's allies. The vagueness of that pledge only heightens the average voter's suspicions about the effectiveness of international organizations like the United Nations.
 For the argument to work, Mr. Kerry must show that he understands the limits of existing international institutions and present a plan to create a new one. He could say something like this: ''Fifty years ago, at the dawn of the cold war, America led our allies in the creation of a new institution to fight communism. That institution was NATO. While NATO remains vital to our security, the world today faces a new threat, and we need a new institution, a new alliance to fight the war against Al Qaeda and its allies. President Bush should have built that new alliance. He has failed. I will not.''
 John Kerry has begun to make the case that the president's adherence to failed policies shows not strength of character, but weakness. To turn that critique into victory, however, Mr. Kerry is going to have to show some character, too -- by being honest as well as bold.
